We have just heard an extraordinary litany of the vindictiveness, of the petty nature and of the petulance of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) towards his Cabinet colleagues, more particularly towards the former Minister for Industrial Relations. It was a searing indictment of how Cabinet is conducted by Prime Minister Fraser. The response of the Prime Minister was smug, as one would have anticipated. He said that Cabinet operates to his satisfaction. With that simple statement he appeared to think that he had repudiated the serious charges which have been levelled before the Parliament.

The fact is that the Prime Minister's statement was a chronicle of banalities. It did not address itself to the central issue. What is more significant in all of this is that the clash today between the Prime Minister and the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) was a clash of style and personality more than anything else. What is equally clear is that one of them is particularly careless in handling the truth but that both have a great deal to answer for on matters that need to be developed further in this Parliament. What is also quite patently obvious is that the great issue that was to go off with a loud bang today only got to the point of a squeak. The public is the loser in this. What is clear is that the Government is disunited. It is in turmoil. It is stricken by turbulence which is undermining its ability to govern the country.

For a fortnight the public has been watching the day by day turmoil of a government locked in serious internal conflict. The Prime Minister and one of his most senior Ministers have been engaged in a deadly exchange. The sum product of this extraordinary turbulence has been the destruction of one Minister; the tarnished reputation of the Prime Minister more deeply scarred; the Government steeped in dissension and disarray; and the process of government paralysed for several weeks as this unedifying public brawl came to a head. The real issue is not whether the honourable member for Kooyong is right or wrong or whether the Prime Minister is correct and proper in their respective conduct; rather it is the concern that the public feels about a confused and disunited government and the fact that the community has to pay a high price for it. The deplorable quality of national government is summed up in one critical statistic. The resignation of the Minister for Industrial Relations is the fifteenth resignation, stand-down or sacking from the Fraser Ministry in only five years. The Fraser Government is crumbling under the corrosive disabling influences of its own internal discord and conflict. There is no hero or villain in today's episode of the Fraser Government engaged in its latest binge of self-destructiveness. There is no black or white knight. This is a nasty and damaging episode in which all participants share culpability. I repeat that it is the Australian public which pays the price of national government distracted and in turmoil and the price of neglect of bad government.

A vast and unflattering range of charges and counter-charges has been made by today's participants in the leadup to this conflict over the past fortnight. The whole process has been vulgar and unedifying. The Prime Minister assured us that the former Minister for Industrial Relations is impetuous, emotionally unstable, fickle, pathologically insecure and implacably petulant. That is bad enough, but the former Minister for Industrial Relations is not to be outdone. He bluntly accused the Prime Minister of treachery, in fostering the publication of personally damaging reports against him with malicious intent, of impulsive and unpredictable behaviour, of an obsessive and marked determination to have his own way, of treating the Cabinet as a cipher, of being an alien to fundamental liberal principles and of being spiritually more at home with the National Country Party and, for good measure, added that the Prime Minister is mentally unstable. The dirty washing of the Government is decked out in grim array for all to see. The Australian Financial Review editorial summed up the situation this morning pretty well. The article stated:

Today Andrew Peacock and Malcolm Fraser both have to justify themselves. This might be difficult, since to a cynical observer it might appear that so far they have been telling nothing but the truth about each other.
That seems to have been confirmed today. The editorial concludes:
The worst possible result today would be a mere listing by each of the contenders of the other's failings. It is up to Mr Peacock to make it more.

He did not make it more. He gave a list of issues about which he felt he had a justifiable grievance. We were expecting the big bang. It was not even a whimper. It was a tiny squeak. He has been frozen out of the economics affairs committees and procedures in the Cabinet and has been circumvented in the deliberations of the razor gang. He stated that he and the Prime Minister had some conflict about the 35-hour working week campaign. That was no surprise to anyone. He said that the Co-ordination Committee considered matters about which he was concerned and he was not involved. He stated that the Prime Minister lobbied Ministers. My God, I have to tell the House that is no novelty. In fact, all these things, I seem to remember, in some degree or other-nowhere near as large as this-are experiences of former Cabinet Ministers serving in this Parliament. I do not wish to go into all the issues which he has raised because, quite frankly, it was a thin set of complaints of 'principle' that the former Minister raised.

The spectacular achievement of the Prime Minister in responding, however, was to make the rather thin explanation of the honourable member for Kooyong look impressive. The substantive matter, which is the only matter on which we should deliberate for any time at all, concerns the recognition of the Pol Pot administration. Bear in mind that among other issues of principle that the former Minister complained about was that tendency of the Prime Minister to go outside Cabinet and to seek to go around collective responsibility. In the statement that the former Minster made to the Parliament he said that he adopted a number of tactics in an effort to win on this issue of principle. He spoke out publicly outside Cabinet-the very thing which he has condemned. He stated that he resigned, that that was withdrawn and that he threatened to resign. Five months later he resigned on this matter of principle which was settled in October of last year-six months ago. He claims that he won, but there is a rather curious and perplexing aspect about this.

I put it to the House that the honourable member for Kooyong deliberately clouded this issue. The Government did vote in favour of accepting the credentials of the Pol Pot regime at the last session of the United Nations, as the former Minister well knows. It is a very thin and fine technicality to argue that the Government nonetheless withdrew recognition of the Pol Pot claim to control of Kampuchea. The former Minister supported this. The Government voted for this recognition of the credentials of the Pol Pot delegation at the United Nations last October. What does this mean? It means that it compelled Australia to accept the Pol Pot regime in the United Nations and its specialised agencies for the whole of 1981. That is not new information. The honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) was kind enough to remind me of it. He has raised these points before in the Parliament. I leave the House with this very sober thought for consideration: If this matter was such an enormous matter or issue of principle why did the Minister not resign before this? Why was he prepared to accept an extension for 12 months of the recognition of a particularly odious administration which he has said he persistently condemned and which he could bear no part of as a matter of principle?

What has happened today is that we have seen a clash of style and personalities. We have seen conflict. The conflict which is evident on this occasion is only the latest of a long record of internal dissention and turmoil within the Fraser Government. It will not be the last conflict of personalities and style because members of the Government do not have any principles and they do not have any great policies. The Fraser Government is the most self-destructively turbulent of any in the history of this country. There are no winners in the Government ranks in this brawl, just losers. The Prime Minister loses little because he loses dignity. He has little of that left. The former Minister for Industrial Relations loses mightily because his resignation looks for all the world as if it comes from a trap craftily set by the Prime Minister into which he impulsively jumped. There is every evidence that the former Minister, as the Prime Minister has claimed publicly is his tendency, wilted under the heat.

The most serious and damaging aspect of this whole sorry state of affairs is the clear evidence it provides of the disarray and disintegration of the Fraser Government. Equally as serious is the manner in which the Government has sat immobilised for weeks as a government, preoccupied by this destructive personality conflict. There are matters of fact, however, which establish the erratic nature of national government under the Fraser Government and which are symptomatic of its congenital inability to work as a team for the good government of Australia. I have mentioned the most notorious of them. There have been 15 resignations, stand downs or dismissals from the Fraser Ministry in five years. Only 14 members of the original Fraser Ministry remain today although the period that has elapsed is so short. Friend and foe are bowled over like nine pins from the Ministry. I mention the three most notable. Vic Garland-he took the rap for the Government on a bribery charge. His reward? He was pushed out of government. Eric Robinson fought a proper and decent fight in defence of the Queensland branch of the Liberal Party. He was subjected by the Prime Minister and especially his National Country Party colleagues in the Ministry to extraordinary pressures and, finally, to inexcusable humiliation. Then there is Senator Withers, the fall guy in an effort to rig the electorate boundaries. He is now stranded on the back benches of the Senate like a large saurian, unblinking, and biding his time and waiting for his chance to strike back. The Ministry has become a Bermuda Triangle for the ambitions of the Prime Minister's friends and foes alike. Look at the letter in today's Age, unsourced, which points out that that much vaunted meeting of Liberal Party officials last Friday, allegedly endorsing the Prime Minister as its representative, did no such thing. It mentions Sir John Atwill of the Liberal Party. I shall quote the contents of the statement so the record is straight. It states:

Sir John's statement last Friday declared that 'representatives of all State parties stressed their divisions' total support for the Prime Minister. The letter leaked last night is highly damaging to the Prime Minister and his supporters . . .
The report goes on:

. . . all those attending the meeting of Liberal Party officials had been in the 'difficult position of wishing to express their organisation's support for Malcolm Fraser in the position of Prime Minister-in other words, support for whoever the Prime Minister may be at the time'.

There is not much dedication there. I understand that letter comes from Queensland, from Dr Herron, the President of the Liberal Party in that State. There is a picturesque quality to the membership and the behaviour of the Fraser Ministry, to the quality of the government which he provides. It is exemplified by the plotting and the counterplotting that have been going on within the ranks of the Government unremittingly for the past five and a half years. We have heard a litany of some of it today, but it represents only the tip of the iceberg.

Where are the great issues of principle? Where are the philosophical inspirations we were going to hear from the honourable member for Kooyong today? All he is seeking to do is to capture a coalition of malcontents on the back bench of the House of Representatives and the Senate; the free traders-he has never given any evidence of being a free trader in his days as Minister for Foreign Affairs-the discontents over Western Australian air fares; the States' righters in relation to Commonwealth-State finances; the members from Victoria and Queensland unhappy with the way in which the Prime Minister runs the Party; the anti-Country Party forces, which are not insignificant; and the largest group of dissidents of all-the anti-Fraser group. The Government is more interested in self-disablement, like the pyromaniac who wants to jump into his own fire, than it is in governing this country.

The genesis of these problems goes back some time. It goes back to Victorian factionalism. It goes back to the Liberal Party push in Gippsland and Peter Nixon's retribution more recently to even up the score-the vindictiveness in retaliation for the old wounds that were opened up on that occasion. That is the basis of the attack on Barry Simon. It goes back to 1971, to the clash between Gorton as Prime Minister and Peacock as the Minister for the Army and Fraser as the Minister for Defence.

Malcolm Fraser has proved that he has a long memory. He has set a trap for the honourable member for Kooyong and he has caught him. Australia is in trouble because of all of this. It is ambushed deep in the heartland of pay-back politics in the Liberal and Country parties. While this sordid affair goes on-and it will-it will be sapping the energies and diverting the attention of the Government from governing. The big problems will get bigger. The issues of increasingly costly housing, rising interest rates, skyrocketing unemployment, the failure of the Government to define a coherent policy in relation to mineral development in this country and the way in which the resource wealth will be shared, and shared fairly, are only a few of the issues that deserve to be considered before this Parliament. The fact that there are only five Bills on the Notice Paper-there are a number of statements of no consequence but there are only five minor Bills which were placed on the Notice Paper only last week-is an indication of how bereft of creative parliamentary work the Government is at present.

Too much of what has masqueraded as political exchange in the past fortnight is more suited for the gossip pages of the scandal newspaper. In that sense it seems appropriate that the whole thing should have been brought to a head by a planted article in the Australian on 14 April. I do not want to canvass that issue. It has been done already by both participants. I sincerely hope that neither expects us to adjudicate on which of the two we are supposed to support. We are left stunned at the relevations which have been made, at the depth of bitterness which is evident and the impairment of the proper functions of government which arise because of this disabling behaviour of members of the Ministry. But we are certainly not going to set ourselves up as some sort of conciliation and arbitration court. A scourge on both their houses. It is a clash of style and a clash of personality. It is nothing greater than that and it deserves to be condemned on that basis, and both of them deserve to be repudiated on those grounds.

It is a trivial pretext on the part of the Prime Minister to bring about this crisis-the Simon resignation. What has he done about the conflict of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) with basic policy of the Government? What has he done about the overrunning in Cabinet solidarity in relation to taxation policy? What has he done about his going to the Gold Coast and proposing flat tax in direct conflict with Government policy? More recently he was in direct conflict with the Government in relation to Trans-Australia Airlines. The Government has double standards. Fierce retribution against the weak cannot be silenced against others.

The former Minister says that the Prime Minister could have killed all the speculation and the problems with a refutation of the article in the Australian on 14 April. How ironic. On 9 March 1971 the Prime Minister, then Minister for Defence just resigned, said:
One sentence would have killed that report.

He was complaining then of planted articles in the Packer newspapers, now owned by Sir Rupert Murdoch or rather Mr Rupert Murdoch-I am a little ahead of the event. The very same thing has been complained about today by the man who was then the Minister for the Army. If he had stood up and taken a firm line in defence of Gorton, who despite whatever shortcomings he may have, is a far better man and far better Australian than this Prime Minister will ever be, the course of events would have been considerably different.

But the situation is not Fraser's fault alone. Those advising him and those closest to him, his spiritual brothers, his hobby farmers from the Country Party, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon), the Deputy Prime Minister, and the part time undertaker, are the people who share responsibility with him. These are the people who are passing on to him the advice as to how he should be handling this matter. However, the major problem is the Prime Minister's erratic ambition. For 15 years he has been at the centre of confrontation and division within Australian politics and its economy. He has an apparently insatiable ambition, an ego needing constant crises on which to feed to prove itself. In the meantime the country is divided. The problem goes back a long way, long before the 15 resignations, stand-downs, dismissals I have mentioned. There was the conflict with Gorton in 1970 and in 1975 the destruction of you, Mr Speaker. If you had been Prime Minister of a Liberal-Country Party Government in 1975 the atmosphere in this country would have been considerably different, and the atmosphere today would have been remarkably better.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable gentleman ought to return to his subject.

—The fact is that the Prime Minister is pathologically incapable of working harmoniously with any team of people. He now proposes to put Mr Viner in as the Minister for Industrial Relations. That is like returning industrial relations to the stone age. The Minister for Industrial Relations has never been inhibited by shame, or discouraged by humiliation. He is ever ready to do his master's bidding with spaniel-like enthusiasm. In Aboriginal affairs the strategy of cheat and deceive at the expense of the Aboriginal has prevailed.
—Order! The honourable gentleman is not entitled to use those words about a Minister who is not subject to the motion.
—I withdraw them.
—I ask the honourable member to withdraw.
—I do withdraw. He was a failure there, he will be a failure in this important role.
—Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired. Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. In so doing I want to make it very clear that this is a motion which should be voted on with an independent frame of mind, and one in relation to which the members of the Liberal Party at least can exercise their great liberalism to find out whether this country is being properly managed. The motion which has been introduced will enable all honourable gentlemen opposite to judge the issue which has been put before this Parliament today. The issue is one of no confidence in the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). Certainly, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) would need to support the motion because his whole litany in this place today has been about a man who is unfit to rule. He used words such as 'irreconcilable', 'manic obsession' and 'inability to consult'. We have been shown an aspect of somebody who is not entitled to be a Minister let alone the Prime Minister. It is hard to work out whether this is an epilogue or a prologue. It is hard to work out who is coming and who is going. The issue is that this nation has never been in a more pitiful situation. We have never placed much weight on what the Government says.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the record. If, as the honourable member for Kooyong said, he was very concerned about recognition of Pol Pot-he should have been-let me remind the Prime Minister and all Ministers of the many attempts we made throughout 1980 to get the Government to derecognise the Pol Pot regime as a genocidal regime. We spoke about this matter from February 1980 until the time the Parliament was dissolved. I asked a question in March 1980 of the then Minister for Foreign Affairs. The question, in part, stated:

. . . how does the Government react to the comment made by Pol Pot's henchman, Khieu Samphan, that Australian support was precious to the Pol Pot regime and that Pol Pot counted Australia amongst his closest supporters.

That question was asked in March 1980. The reply stated: 'Well, of course, it is a political matter and there have been some discussions and perhaps there will be a political solution'. Why was the answer not given then that that regime did not deserve recognition, even in March 1980? Again, I raised the matter in August 1980 in a discussion on human rights. I said:
Two Australians were executed by the Pol Pot regime.

They were Ronald Keith Dean and David Lloyd Scott. Their offence, it is said, was to sail too close to the Kampuchean coast. Their butcher, the camp commandant, subsequently escaped to Thailand where he was fed by aid. His name is Duch. He has now returned to Kampuchea with a promotion, as Security Officer in the Central Committee of the Pol Pot faction Communist Party. It turns out that the confession of David Lloyd Scott was signed . . . on 12 December 1978.
I ask honourable members to mark that date. My remarks continued:
On 13 December 1978, this Government announced that it had decided to open negotiations with Pol Pot with a view to entering into diplomatic relations.

Where is the substance of what this debate is about except the dishonesty of what has been happening and what has been put forward to the Australian people? The real issue of that debate at that time related to something else. It was this: I continued in that debate in August 1980 by saying that this country had a Foreign Minister who allegedly did not want to recognise Pol Pot but had to do so because the Prime Minister had had a discussion with Chairman Hua of China and had guaranteed Chairman Hua that he would continue to recognise Pol Pot because that was in agreement with Chinese foreign policy. So it is on record right throughout 1980 that the two gentlemen who are the subject of the debate today were in cahoots as to what ought to be done, paid no mind to the deaths of the two Australians which occurred in 1978 and at the same time as the deaths occurred urged that diplomatic relations be established. That is one example.

The issue today for the Australian people to judge is this: Who is entitled to lead this country? Where are the principles of these two people and where is their integrity concerning Cabinet solidarity and ministerial responsibility? I accept the word of the honourable member for Kooyong that Cabinet is a one-man Cabinet. The Prime Minister runs the lot. He spoke about the fracturing of Cabinet government which has taken place. Power has been centralised in one man. How can we have effective government if that is the situation? Is it not true, as the honourable member for Kooyong said, that he was not included in any matter of substance because he was virtually on the way out. We can see that is true because he has mentioned today how he was feeling the situation back in 1980. The wonder of it is why he accepted a portfolio in this new ministry in view of what happened in 1980.

The Prime Minister made the point that he wondered why the honourable member for Kooyong took eight months to come to a decision on his resignation. Perhaps the honourable member for Kooyong was following the precedent set by the right honourable gentleman in 1971. Let us place on record the fact that when the Prime Minister was Minister for Defence he resigned in March 1971 and made a statement to this House about what he thought of the then Prime Minister, Mr Gorton. He made that statement on the basis that there had been a call-out order for the Pacific Island Regiment in July 1970. He said that he was not consulted about it. The significant part of that is that the present Prime Minister, when he was Minister for Defence, did nothing about it for eight months. So there is some significance in that eight-month delay. The same situation applies in this case. It was said at that time that if Mr Fraser had felt aggrieved by any action of Mr Gorton regarding the call-out order he should have properly resigned. He chose not to do so. He let eight months go by before voicing his complaint. So there is some consistency in the two situations, although the Prime Minister has some syndrome about there being an eight-month gap before one faces up to the fact that one should resign from a Cabinet in which one has no support at all.

I think the other matters are very important ones. They are matters which were touched on by the Prime Minister. They concern how well the Government is doing. If that is an issue we want to widen this motion of no confidence to encompass the whole of the Government and not just the Prime Minister. We did not know what was happening until we heard the statements which have been made today. They are lightweight in their content but very heavy in their indictment of the tragic sort of Cabinet we have governing this country. It is a Cabinet that cannot get its own act together. When a Liberal Minister is in trouble with his Prime Minister, who is called in to act as peacemaker? It is the Country Party Ministers who are called in. Never at any stage did we see any senior Liberal Ministers involved. It was Country Party Ministers who told the honourable member for Kooyong how the situation could perhaps be solved. That might explain some of the problems that the country is now facing, because it is a case of a coalition-I emphasise the word 'coalition'-of two parties with two different policies having a tug-of-war all the time, and the country is making no progress.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were good enough to defeat you people and get into office.

—The Deputy Prime Minister ought to talk. He is a flat tax man if ever there was one and he was unable to do anything about it. He is the man who does not want to sell Trans-Australia Airlines when the others do. Where does he stand on these issues? Why does he not resign? Where are his principles? His party is a rump party hanging on to the Liberal Party which gives out the bones. He hangs on to that situation, and that is how he has operated and continues to operate. Let us look at the situation existing in this country. We have half a million unemployed people in Australia; inflation is soaring; the 90 day bond interest rate on bank bills is now 17 per cent and nobody can get a housing loan.
—Tell the truth.

—The Minister for Housing and Construction ought to talk. People cannot afford to pay mortgages these days because interest rates have escalated to 15 per cent, 16 per cent, and 17 per cent. Another Minister talks about hospitals and how this Government is helping the hospitals. Because of this Government's inability to get a health program going we find that State governments have to provide additional funding to help the additional 12 per cent of people who go to hospitals because they cannot afford doctors. Why is that? The reason is that people cannot keep up their insurance premiums. How many people are in health insurance funds today? The answer is less than 50 per cent of the population. So all the hospitals in the country are breaking down on two issues. They have to treat at least 12 per cent more patients and, because so many people are uninsured, the hospitals cannot collect the same fees they were collecting before. These are the fundamental issues. Is there any wonder that we have these problems when the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations are squabbling on the issues of what they think of each other instead of having what should be a fundamental unity of purpose to carry out the Government's so-called mandate to guarantee good economic government which it received at the last election.

SPEECH.PARA: I now come to the industrial matters that were raised by the honourable member for Kooyong. Certainly, he has been trampled underfoot. Certainly he has been of no significance in any matter of industrial relations. He has not been of any significance because the Prime Minister has taken over the running of the issues, as he does on any issue except that of making a statement in this House. Today was the first time that the right honourable gentleman has made a statement. Incredibly it was prepared in advance to answer a statement which was to be made by the honourable member for Kooyong and which the Prime Minister had not seen. That might be why we have to educate the people of Australia to look at the tragic record of the Prime Minister in the industrial relations area. This record goes back a long way. In 1977 we were going to be called back to a special session of this Parliament to deal with the air traffic controllers' dispute in Tasmania. But luckily the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) was able to settle the matter without the Prime Minister. Honourable members opposite know that that happened. Honourable members will remember the problems at the Redfern Mail Exchange. In this instance the Government rushed in immediately with another piece of emergency legislation to enable a Minister of the Government to stand down any employee. The employees had no rights at all. Then we had the Telecom dispute in which the Prime Minister rushed into this Parliament and said that not one person on strike would get paid. Of course, that dispute was settled on a Sunday 48 hours later and all employees received their back pay.

Thank God for Mr Justice Moore when we look at section 45D of the Trade Practices Act. The disputes concerning Gorman and Laidely that cost this country millions and millions of dollars were settled only because of the intervention of Mr Justice Moore who used his conciliatory ability-the legislation of this Parliament was against him-to get the parties together and to get the whole of the machinery of business back to work. The Prime Minister appeared on the late late show with John Singleton and said that it had nothing to do with him, that it was a State matter. That is how he acts.

The recent radar dispute has been mentioned in this debate. I would say that this dispute sent East West Airlines Ltd to the mortgagees for a start. The dispute, which went on for a long while, could have been settled by the former Minister for Industrial Relations. It could have been settled and would have been settled but the Prime Minister said: 'No, it is not to be done'. A working party of the Department of Transport had been working for two years on the cause of that dispute and had agreed on a settlement. This shows the sort of solidarity in the Cabinet. The terms and conditions of a settlement had been agreed upon. It was agreed that there would be a reclassification of radar technicians. That was the way that the dispute should have been settled. But no, the Prime Minister intervened. With the Public Service Board at his heels he took Mr Cole to Cabinet and said: 'No, you cannot settle that dispute'. So the Government paralysed the nation with that dispute.

The Government ought to have a look at what Ansett and others think of its ability in the industrial relations field because the dispute cost them millions of dollars. The matter is now back in the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on a proper basis and I hope it will be settled. The then Minister for Transport knew that a working party had been working on industrial relations in this area for two years. One should not trample that work under foot simply because one was Prime Minister.

Let me turn to the Government's record in the Altona dispute. The parties in this dispute were in discussion. They were talking about setting up working parties. The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission had agreed that working parties would be set up to discuss the matter on a proper basis. The working parties were to conduct an investigation over three months during which time all industrial action would be halted. But the Prime Minister made a statement which said: 'No, there is to be no consultation, no discussion, no question of a 35-hour week'. As a result employees again went back to strike action.

The ICI dispute was referred to this afternoon. The game was given away very clearly by the honourable member for Kooyong when he told the House what he thought about the situation. Certainly his secretary Mr Barry Simon was right when he said there was a lack of an honest approach by certain people to make a point. It is very clear when one looks at the profits of the chemical industry which are escalating by 33 per cent every year that some fat should be given to employees because of increased productivity. But again we have a Prime Minister who is demanding that the chairman of ICI Aust. Ltd come to Canberra to make a statement contrary to what he had already told the Premier of New South Wales. He was told that he had to make the statement if he did not want to be hauled before the Industries Assistance Commission. This was the threat that was handed out.

I have given a summary of recent matters. Is this not an indictment of the Government? You would not allow the Prime Minister and the honourable member for Kooyong into your waiting room if you were trying to run a business. You would go broke because of all the squabbling between the two. We should look at where this country is going. The Opposition wants intelligent debate on matters that affect everybody in Australia. We should not be talking about who is to run the Liberal Party. The Government is completely incompetent. We now know that it is the National Country Party that is running the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Kooyong in a display of mock indignation made a speech to the House. Over the last week or two we have witnessed the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) making a brutal attack on the honourable member for Kooyong on television programs, in the Press and now in the Parliament. The honourable member for Kooyong talked about his being appointed to the Monetary Committee. The Prime Minister replied to that and said it was a committee about interest rates and exchange rates. Instead of that, he squibbed it, as he has done on so many occasions. Then, on the flight to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in India, he told the Prime Minister about the deaths of a number of Australian yachtsmen at the hands of the Pol Pot Government. He said to the Prime Minister that these were altered circumstances. What would alter the circumstances-the death of two men compared to the death of millions in Kampuchea at the hands of Pol Pot? Would there be altered circumstances because the yachtsmen happened to be white, caucasian, Australian? Would that have made some alteration to the circumstances?

Frankly, I do not blame the Prime Minister for not taking any notice of what the honourable member for Kooyong said about his resignation. To that extent, it became obvious to all of us that the honourable member for Kooyong had no place in the Fraser Cabinet. That is simply a matter of politics; it is a matter of how the honourable member for Kooyong handled his politics. Obviously, wittingly or otherwise, he painted himself into a corner. He probably did not want to live under the Fraser Government, but he should have resigned. He had the opportunity but pulled out.

The speech of the honourable member for Kooyong was a disgrace. It was a display of mock indignation and petulance. It was an attempt to establish matters of principle. It had nothing to do with matters of principle; he simply saw a chance to grab the leadership of the Liberal Party. The Cabinet sensed that. In all of the years of the Fraser Government we have never had any more than two or three speakers in any debate but the Deputy Prime Minister is here, the Minister for Industry and Commerce has returned from the ashes to speak for the first time in a debate for about five years, to my knowledge, and we have the hired gun of the National Country Party, the Minister for Primary Industry, sitting here. TALK.START.PARA: —You are whistling in the dark, old boy.

—The Deputy Prime Minister says I am whistling in the dark. He is very pleased with the situation because now graziers alone run the Cabinet of Australia. The only interest in the Cabinet which was not that of a grazier, which was an urban Liberal interest, was that of the honourable member for Kooyong. Now he is out, the graziers are in full swing. SPEECH.PARA: I ask honourable members to look at the record of the Government in recent times. There is vacillation on health policy; the Government does not know what to do with the present health scheme. We have seen vacillation on the airline policy. We have seen two or three tax policies floated in the last three or four months. There is no discussion in Cabinet; matters are floated in the newspapers to see what the editorial comment is like and then the Government recedes from a proposal or goes on with it. There has been no decision about taxation. There is vacillation in regard to Commonwealth-State relations, and the situation is similar in regard to the Broadcasting and Television Act and resources policy. The Government talks about how the average family will benefit from the development of Australian resources, but the Government does not have a policy. In fact, it has no policy about anything. It is this very vacillation which has produced this set of circumstances which has flushed the honourable member for Kooyong into the open and turned the Cabinet against him.

So, the tide is running out for the Government simply because it has no ideas. It has no strategy for Australia and it has no leadership. We have had five years of the Fraser Government. What do we have to show for it? We have abysmal, pathetic rates of economic growth. The rates are half those which obtained during the period of the Whitlam Government in the early 1970s. This week we have seen that inflation is off and running again with the highest consumer price index in the March quarter for four years. It is back to double digits after six years of hard slog under the Fraser Government. Interest rates are at their highest in Australian history, with deposit rates up to 17 per cent. I do not refer to certificates of deposit, that flighty piece of paper that we see occasionally, but to the firm deposit policy of the banks. The rate is 17 per cent. Unemployment is at record levels and rising. Where is the progress? Unemployment, inflation rates and interest rates are all up and there is low economic growth. The little economic growth we have seen in the early part of this year will be choked off by the high interest rates which prevail in the economy. Young people cannot afford to house themselves and working people cannot service a mortgage. They are not covered with health protection and again their standards of living will decline dramatically.

All of this is because the Fraser Government simply has run out of ideas, out of policies. It is bereft of policies and is now searching for some basis of philosophy. We see in the House today Professor Kemp and three other professors lined up behind the Government front bench in the official's box. They are here to give some philosophical basis to the meanderings of the Liberal Party and its Prime Minister. They are back to put the show in order. Neither the Cabinet, nor the Liberal or Country Party ministers, the drones of the front bench, can do so. They need to get the professors from Monash University or some other place to add some Ayn Rand quality or some mix of Ayn Rand and Friedmanism to the Liberal Party's philosophical basis on which to hang its policies.

The Government is in chaos. It has no policies and no ideas. It does not know what to do with Australia in the 1980s. We are in the early part of the 1980s and the Government has no idea what to do. We see sitting at the back of the House all of the other heirs apparent looking at what is happening today. Most importantly, we see those who support the honourable member for Kooyong. What a motley crowd they are. They are the free marketeers, the people who believe in absolute free enterprise. What they have in common with the honourable member for Kooyong I will never know. Senator Withers, the toe cutter, is beached on the back benches of the Senate waiting to get at the Prime Minister. Senator Rae from Tasmania has his nose out of joint. What a motley crowd! What a natural cohesion! The truth is that there is no common thread of policy or politics. There is no common political thought between the honourable member for Kooyong and his supporters. It is an anti-Fraser group, married and matched to the drys, the economic rationalists and the Melbourne establishment built around the honourable member for Kooyong. That is the group which faces the Prime Minister.

Then there are the other heirs apparent such as the Treasurer (Mr Howard) who is the mouthpiece of the Prime Minister. He could not get a piece of toilet paper through Cabinet without the support of the Prime Minister. He has no chance of getting anywhere with his Cabinet. The honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) is the Minister for Health. Fancy damning Australia with this negative, unimaginative product from Sydney's north shore. Is that what we have to tolerate for the future cause of liberalism in this country? Is that the likely leadership? Is that all the Liberal Party has to offer? Obviously, the choice will be for the Australian Labor Party. Members of the Government realise that.

Today signals the demise of the Fraser Government and the coalition. The Labor Party will be back to power at the next election as a result. What has happened here today has not concerned a matter of principle involving leaks to journalists and having stories corraborated and backgrounded. It has not been about Kampuchea. Andrew Peacock understood the Government's position on Kampuchea. It was committed to recognising a murderous and barbarous regime. The Prime Minister even got the Prime Minister of Singapore to make a statement in support of him. There was no way that the Government would change its opinion. It changed only under pressure from the honourable member for Kooyong. Even after that he resigned. There was no place for him in the Fraser Cabinet. The policy directions of the Cabinet and the influence of the Country Party cut urban Liberals out of it. Urban Liberals are trying to get back into the role of government within the coalition. That is what this row is about. That is what has produced this division.

This division will remain. It is a basic deep-rooted division which will destroy the stability of the Government. The problem for Australia is that even a solid Cabinet would have difficulties hatching policy for the 1980s to meet the problems Australia faces. In the light of this division there will be no chance. When a government starts to disintegrate it seems that nothing can stop it. This Government is disintegrating. It deserves to disintegrate. If the Government did the decent thing and talked about the reprehensible circumstances it talked about five years ago it would resign and give a decent united party a chance to govern Australia in the national interest. That party is the Australian Labor Party. We will be back much sooner than we thought.

SPEECH.PARA: The massive allegations made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) today in his censure motion of the Prime Minister were based on the allegations made by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). I know that the Prime Minister has spent countless hours on many occasions with the honourable member for Kooyong discussing problems and difficulties that the honourable member might have had. The Prime Minister has shown infinite patience in trying to resolve any misunderstandings and difficulties there might have been.

When the honourable member for Kooyong wanted to resign in the middle of last year I became involved. Why? As Deputy Prime Minister of this Government I did not want to see the honourable member resign when we were heading towards an election in a few months' time. I talked to the honourable member and tried to put my point of view. That view was the unanimous view of Cabinet that we should not derecognise the Pol Pot regime at that time. It was not only the Prime Minister's point of view. Everyone of us had exactly the same point of view. I was pleased that we found a means of coping with that situation. We decided to keep the matter under review and that the honourable member could make a further submission to a Cabinet.

I think it was regrettable that the honourable member for Kooyong took such an intransigent attitude towards the Pol Pot regime on the eve of an election. Be that as it may. The issue that really triggered the resignation of the honourable member was the Barry Simon episode. The honourable member's private secretary made public statements which were unacceptable to the Government. These factors ought to be remembered when we are considering the whole matter because it was that issue that triggered his resignation. The honourable member for Kooyong has described the Prime Minister's response to Mr Simon's actions as evidence of the Prime Minister's so-called obsessive nature. Mr Simon did not, as the media seems to have put it in shorthand form, merely make comments about the Government's handling of the 35-hour week in relation to the ICI issue. He spoke of a number of matters. In his introductory remarks he said that he would discuss the breakdown in party disciplines and party administration. He said that he would mention the development of a presidential-style administration moving away from the Westminster system. He mentioned the dominance of the Executive over Parliament and the irrelevance of Parliament and its members. Then he got on to the subject of the 35-hour week. He said that he thought that there was distortion and lack of an honest approach by certain people and manipulation to their own ends.

Mr Simon's remarks were made at a meeting to a substantial number of people including a journalist. Remarks of this nature, even in private conversation, would have represented at the least an indiscretion on the part of a senior member of a Minister's staff. Made as they were at a session of a national convention of the Australian Society of Association Executives, the remarks took on an even more serious aspect. He criticised the way the Government was run, the way the Prime Minister acted, the way the Liberal Party operated and the attitude of the Executive to the Parliament and private members. To my mind from the moment he made those remarks there could be no question whatsoever about Mr Simon's not continuing in his job. There was no other course to be followed but that he should resign, be asked to resign or be dismissed. The simple fact is that no government can work as it should if its own servants are free to make public comments critical of the government and its policies and actions or the people in it. People can make high-minded assertions about freedom of speech and all the rest but the fact is that government servants, indeed servants of any organisation, must accept certain constraints as part of their responsibility. They need to accept these limitations on their own actions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Freedom is dangerous, Doug.

—The honourable member should not talk. The Labor Party certainly applies constraints on anybody who opens his mouth. SPEECH.PARA: One of the matters that have been put forward as significant is the allegation of the failure of the Prime Minister to observe the requirements of the Cabinet system of administration and decision making. It has been suggested that the proper procedures have been bypassed, that there has been either not enough consultation amongst Ministers or too much consultation with too few Ministers before matters are considered by Cabinet. Perhaps I am in a better position than anyone else in this House to comment on these assertions which I clearly do not accept. I have been a member of ministries led by six Prime Ministers. I have been a deputy Prime Minister to three of them. After almost 24 years as a member of this Parliament and 14 years as a Minister, I believe that I am fairly well-qualified to express views on the working of Cabinets and Ministries as I have known them.

The plain fact is that under the present Prime Minister the decision-making processes of the Government are more formal, more efficient and better organised than in any other Cabinet of which I have been a member. The Cabinet committee system has become more highly developed and organised under the present Prime Minister than under any other. A range of Cabinet committees has been set up so that there can be adequate consideration given to the increasingly wide range of matters coming before the Cabinet. This was quite impossible under a previous system in which there were many ad hoc committees. These committees are made up of Ministers from the Cabinet and those outside of the Cabinet. In this way it is possible to involve Ministers in a thorough consideration of the matters coming before the Government.

One of the most important of these committees is the Co-ordination Committee. I have seen suggestions to the effect that there is something to be concerned about in having a co-ordination committee. There is nothing surreptitious or secretive about the existence of this committee, its membership or its responsibilities. The Co-ordination Committee consists of the Prime Minister, me, the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch), the Minister for Communications and Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) and the Minister for National Development and Energy, the Vice-President of the Executive Council and the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick). It is not a coincidence but a sensible and deliberate arrangement that members of the co-ordinating committee are the five most senior Ministers. Of course, four of them are leaders or deputy leaders of their respective parties, the fifth being the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

The responsibilities of this committee are to consider overall Government strategy and priorities and to deal with matters referred to it by the Prime Minister. Previous Prime Ministers have so often made decisions themselves-a responsibility, a right that they have-but the present Prime Minister has found it more satisfactory and wiser to solicit the opinions of senior Ministers. That has been the basic function of that committee-not to caucus on matters to come before Cabinet. I completely reject any such suggestion. It is not a fair allegation to make of the Co-ordination Committee or of the Prime Minister.

I speak on behalf of myself and of the National Country Party. We have complete confidence in and absolute respect for the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister has had the onerous job of revitalising the economy of this country, of getting back a bit of sanity into government. This country is showing great promise. It is moving forward at a time when the rest of the world is having great difficulties. Why is there confidence? Why is this country moving forward? It is because of the way it is being managed. It is because of the standards and the disciplines which the Prime Minister has applied to government. Of course there can be disagreements. I have not always agreed with the Prime Minister. Certainly he lets me know his opinions if he disagrees with me. But this is the way it should be. Ministers must not get incensed if they find that they are wrong or cannot get an agreement from their Cabinet colleagues; that is the working of the Cabinet. It is tragic that we are having this discussion today. Certainly I completely reject the censure motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition. I completely reject the assertions and the allegations that have been made by the honourable member for Kooyong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There would be no doubt as to why the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony), the Leader of the National Country Party, would be so enthusiastic in his support of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). By manipulating the Prime Minister before the elections as to the destiny of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) those men were able to compromise the honourable member for Kooyong to stay in the Ministry before the election for the purposes of the election on the understanding that the honourable member for Wannon, the Leader of the National Country Party, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon), the Deputy Leader of the National Country Party and the now Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair), would have the opportunity following the elections to get the honourable member for Kooyong for having dared to test their policies in the Cabinet in July and again in September of last year on the question of Pol Pot. One readily understands the pressures that might have been brought to bear by members of the Association of South East Asian Nations on this Government's policy. If there had not been an election on 18 October 1980 we would still be recognising Pol Pot. The election was responsible for the Government's change of policy. We would still be recognising Pol Pot if there had not been an election. We can dismiss that. The fact is that the only person on the Government side who was prepared to stand up in this Government, which had a majority of 48 members until the October election, the only person who had the decency and guts to stand up and say 'We should withdraw recognition of Pol Pot', has now been sent to the boundary, the back of the chamber, where he can be of no further influence in the policy-making apparatus of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Kooyong has fallen for the three-card trick. He has been isolated with a few ineffective supporters, such as the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen). It is about time some of these woolly-nosed Liberals woke up to what is going on in this so-called coalition. If one looks at the people who have been stabbed in the back by this Prime Minister one will find that they are all Liberals. They are all members of the Liberal Party. Mr Ian Sinclair got back into the Ministry. He was not kept out in the cold in spite of all the allegations. He won his way back. That was not the case with Reg Withers because he is a Liberal. The events which occurred on the day on which he resigned were quite a joke. On the radio program PM it was stated that this was not the end of the matter because Mr Peacock had the support of Mr Killen. Fair dinkum! That would be like having the Chinese table tennis team behind him. Fancy having the Minister for Defence behind him. He would be looking around all the time. The Minister would be of no help at all. It was also stated on the program that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle was standing behind Mr Peacock. She is a member of the other chamber. Who could be relied upon more than any other member of the Liberal-National Country Party Government in this country, taking into account the 780 members who constitute all the parliaments of Australia? Who could be relied upon to get down on his knees and lick the boots of the Prime Minister? The snide Mr Viner was appointed as Minister for Industrial Relations. He will be down on his knees and it will not matter what the Prime Minister says to him. Mr Viner will carry out the instructions that are given to him. The whole of the Australian body politic has been ridiculed by this affair, this so-called family affair within the Country-Liberal Party. We have been told that the matter is not important because the country is being well run and that the Government had a resounding victory at the last Federal election. Half of a per cent separated the difference in the voting pattern between the people who voted for the coalition government and the people who voted for the Australian Labor Party. In addition to that, the Liberal and National Country parties sold themselves to every major financial institution in this country in order to raise the millions of dollars that were required to buy the votes of the Australian voters. They were not voted back in on the policies they had enunciated and carried out between 1975 and 1980. They bought their way back in like the scum that they are. That is the way in which they will continue to try to hold government in this country, by keeping the electoral laws in such a way that they have this magnificent advantage in that they can take the cheques off all the multinationals who come into Australia in order to reap the millions of dollars that are required.
