—As I said, the reason the Liberal and Country parties' candidates were able to win the election in 1980 was because of the advantage the electoral laws of this country give them in the way in which they are able to raise money from overseas companies in order to buy all the media time that is necessary to influence that additional percentage of votes over the Labor Party. We will get no decent result in the elections of this country until the rotten electoral laws-if I may use that term; I think it is a parliamentary term-of this country are altered so that every person standing for election has an equal chance.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the matters which were raised by the honourable member for Kooyong. First of all, it should not have come as a surprise to him, seeing that he has been in politics for so long, that this Prime Minister likes to dominate everything. On the questions of industrial relations the Prime Minister is absolutely paranoid. He cannot control himself for one instant. Why the honourable member for Kooyong should be surprised about that is difficult to understand. The reason that the Prime Minister gave Mr Street the industrial relations portfolio originally was that they share this beautiful relationship which they have carried on since school that Mr Street never challenges Mr Fraser. The Prime Minister knew that if he put Mr Street in the industrial relations portfolio he would at least sit quietly and would play a different role than Mr Viner. He put Mr Street into that portfolio and, in addition, set up his own department of industrial relations within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in order to ensure that his voice was the important voice on industrial relations in this country.

I say to the honourable member for Kooyong that he should have stayed on the front bench and fought the matter himself because he has no allies. If one looks at the front bench of the Liberal-Country Party coalition Government one will see that there is no one from the Liberal Party who would challenge or in any way argue with the Prime Minister of this country. All his conversations, agreements and conspiracies will be done with the Country Party while all the other members of the Ministry, the MacKellars, the Howards, the Fifes and the Moores, will sit there like dummies and take it. It is the only chance they have. If they raise their voices they will find themselves subject to the same type of conspiracy which the Prime Minister used to oust the honourable member for Kooyong. It is no accident that the honourable member for Kooyong found himself on the back bench a couple of weeks ago. If we look at what fired the matter we will see that it was the leaking of the story to Malcolm Colless of the Australian. It is no surprise to anybody that Malcolm Colless from the Australian should be granted the advantage of receiving the leaks from the Prime Minister's Department.

We have this beautiful relationship in Australia now where News Ltd, proprietors of the Australian, is totally committed to the Fraser Government and the Fraser Government is totally committed to News Ltd. So it is no surprise to anybody that Malcolm Colless should have received the story. The only question is: Who gave it to him? Was it the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) or the Prime Minister? Now there is such a thing as a journalist not letting people know where he gets his stories from. The Minister for Primary Industry is someone who looks forward to the journalists continuing that, because we often read stories coming from his office. When Malcolm Colless was asked where the story came from he did not have to say that he got it from the Prime Minister. He could have said: 'I did not get it from the Prime Minister'. He could have cleared the Prime Minister of Australia by saying: 'No, I did not get the story from that office'. But what did he say? When he was questioned by Richard Carleton he said:
'Okay, then, will you deny, and will you support what Mr Fraser said that it did not come from . . . his office?'
Mr Colless said:
I don't intend to comment at all on that question of where my information comes from.

The journalist was not only not prepared to say where he got his information from but also not prepared to say that it was not the Prime Minister of Australia who gave it to him. He was not protecting informants, unless the Prime Minister was the informant. The honourable member for Kooyong nearly split our sides when he said-following the Prime Minister's statement, that there were inaccuracies in the story that appeared on 14 April-that the Prime Minister, or the Prime Minister's Press secretary, David Barnett, would rectify it. He would have to be joking. Fancy sending David Barnett to the Press Gallery to rectify a story which he has been put in charge of leaking to the journalists. Every Minister will now be subjected to these additional pressures which are going to be placed on them because the Prime Minister has this enormous advantage.

He also has his own little department overseeing every Minister. Now there are some Ministers that he does not have to worry about. He does not have to worry about the Minister for Primary Industry, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) or the Minister for Communications-or rather we should call him the Minister for Rupert Murdoch. He does not have to worry about the Minister for Industrial Relations, as he will be barking all the time. If the Prime Minister does not want to knock over in Cabinet someone who looks as though he is raising his voice against anything the Prime Minister wants to do, and if he does not want him on the agenda for Cabinet meetings then he will just send the big puppy dog from his office, David Barnett. He will say: 'Upstairs, boy'. He will give a whistle and say: 'Just spread this around and we will deny it tomorrow and that should finish that bloke off'.

If we are not reading that sort of thing every day we are reading that the Minister for Defence is heading for Washington, the Minister for Industry and Commerce is hanging on to his seat like death because he is going to be speared overseas somewhere. Overseas posts are not being filled because the Prime Minister cannot decide which Minister should fill them. I will bet that they will all be Liberal Ministers who will be sent. He will not be getting rid of the heavies from the Country Party who are now running this country.

That is the reason we say that in this whole fiasco is a family feud within the Liberal Party. In the eyes of the Australian public the Government shows no decency at all by having this brawl which means absolutely nothing but which brings the Australian body politic down into the gutters. What does it matter to us or to the people outside reading the newspapers, watching the television or listening to the radio whether Malcolm Fraser or Andrew Peacock is Prime Minister? Under either ultra-conservative regime we would still have 500,000 people unemployed; we would still have tens of thousands of people living in poverty. The Government would still refuse to recognise the real social issues and problems of this country. It would still refuse to come to reality with all the sorts of pressures that will build up. It would still refuse to recognise the objectives of the young people who will want to work in the 1980s and the 1990s. It does not matter a damn who is the Prime Minister out of the two who put themselves forward. What does matter is that the people of Australia think a lot less of this institution than they did a fortnight ago because of the actions of this Prime Minister and the way in which he has to get rid of his opponents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) this afternoon delivered to this House a speech which has been culled from all the flowers of St Giles and Billingsgate. The time must wait for a proper dissection of that boisterous and thoroughly vulgar speech. I will await that opportunity at some time in the future. A censure motion, a no-confidence motion, is a matter of high parliamentary principle. I would have thought that that on its own would have encouraged from the Opposition and from the honourable member for Port Adelaide a proper and parliamentary approach to the issue. But alas, it has not. I will await the opportunity of dealing with the honourable gentleman in what I describe as a proper fashion. But there is a further matter of high principle involved, probably as basic a principle to this parliamentary institution as any that I can apprehend. I propose to come to it in short time. It is the whole principle of Cabinet government.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I turn to that, may I say to the House that I would be less than human if I did not at once acknowledge the fact that this is a day of infinite sadness for me. To lose a colleague in government, however the loss may occur, is a sad event. I find the loss of my honourable friend the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) in this fashion a matter of singular sadness. We joined the Ministry together. Some members in the House may recall that I was under obligation to leave that Ministry. I am bound to say in my defence that I left in dramatically different circumstances from which my honourable friend has left the present Ministry. We have been friends for many years. We have shared disappointments, anxieties and a lot of laughs. For the most part we have looked out on the world in striking correspondence of views. The friendship that we have had has suffered grievously by this action. But time has her own balming effect. For the promise of the years of my friend to be so abruptly cut short is a sad business, but the muster of misery is added to infinitely by the manner in which it has been done. But one question must be asked, and I ask it. I only hope that my honourable friend, in charity, will understand the motives that compel me to ask it. I want to put the question before the House and I want it to approach the question as critically and as uncharitably as it may care to. My honourable friend has said: 'The blame for my going from the Government lies with the Prime Minister.' The Prime Minister and the Government say that the blame lies with the honourable member for Kooyong.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you say?

—I am a member of the Government. Does it not show what an impoverished understanding the honourable member has of the principle to ask such a fatuous question. I am dealing with a matter of high principle. I know that this sounds strange to that collection of vulgar and mechanical politicians who have no understanding of the system we are dealing with. This Parliament and the country must make an adjudication of who is right-the honourable member for Kooyong or the Prime Minister and the Government. I want to deal with the principles that are involved in this great issue. An assessment can only be made by a consideration of the most fundamental of principles. I understand the sense of anguish that sweeps through my honourable friend. I can acknowledge the fact that we can all find that sense of courage to endure the anguish of others. I say to my honourable friend that I hope he will understand the sense of anguish that races through many of us in this Parliament and throughout the country today. If he can understand that, then his sense of charity will be acknowledged to be deep. But there remain powerful reasons for me to say to my honourable friend that he is in error in the decision that he has taken. I say to him further that he has transgressed against one of the essential principles of our political society as I understand those principles.

SPEECH.PARA: To address myself to this matter is not a task that I relish. One cannot turn one's back on a quarter of a century of friendship and imagine that it has never existed or that there are not still strong strings of relationship in that friendship. But a sense of duty arouses. One must say blunt and harsh things. Before I turn to that may I turn, albeit in a peripheral way, to some of the views offered this afternoon by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and some of his colleagues. I can acknowledge the fact that this is a heaven-sent opportunity for the Australian Labor Party to exploit what has taken place. That neither surprises me nor dismays me. But neither the frequency nor the ferocity of the criticism that comes from the Australian Labor Party regarding this issue will in any way put the Labor Party in proper light because, as the years between 1972 and 1975 show, its role in seeking to be sententious about parliamentary conduct is a role that can be described only as a vulgar masquarade.

How many honourable members who sit opposite today and who have served in the two governments led by Mr Whitlam would be prepared to give to this House the instances of when they were defeated in the Cabinet and, either on their own account or through the assistance of some other colleague, took the issue into the Caucus. I notice that the honourable member for Capricornia (Dr Everingham) is standing up. There it is! There is the very perversion of the principle that I propose to enunciate. Without shame and without inhibition, constantly and coarsely, the Australian Labor Party has put political principle and regarded it as a mere coquetry of political prostitution. That is a harsh thing to say but it deserves to be said. I want to return to the dominant principle that governs every person who sits in a Cabinet.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're falling to bits.

—I listened to the honourable gentleman in silence. I hope that he can find some sense to understand what I am putting to him. There is one dominant principle that pervades all Cabinet activity and all Cabinet consideration-that is, there is one view and that view must be either respected or ignored. In the case of the Australian Labor Party it has the mechanics whereby it can, as a matter of convenience, overrule that. That is not the case with those, nor should it be the case with those, who acknowledge the strength and proprieties of the Westminster system of parliament and of government.

SPEECH.PARA: I now want to consider the complaints made this afternoon by my honourable friend the honourable member for Kooyong. I think it would be fair to say that the majority of his complaints have been drawn from times when he sat as a member of a government. I only put that; I will not say whether those complaints are right or wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?

—I want to say this to the honourable gentleman opposite: I have never been in the habit, and I do not propose to lapse into the habit, of disclosing what appears before a Cabinet, what business has been conducted before a Cabinet, any decision of a Cabinet, the manner in which that decision has been arrived at or who was in favour of that decision or who was against it. I acknowledge as being utterly sacrosanct in a parliamentary sense that there is one corporate view of a government. If one does not like it, one has one's remedy. For the purposes of illustrating the conviction with which I hold this principle I want to take every charge made by the honourable member for Kooyong as being right. I want to say to him that a Minister sitting in a Cabinet may oppose with skill and with determination the making of a particular decision. But once that decision is taken he has one clear duty: If he does not like it he has the remedy to resign. If he does not like it, that is his remedy. But if he accepts that decision he has a clear duty to defend, in the Parliament and in the public arena, that decision with the same skill and with the same determination with which he opposed it.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not a matter of mere inclination. This is not some dreary sentimental attitude which finds its origins in the dim past. This is a matter that can be identified only as one of inescapable duty. A Minister on many occasions may find himself placed in a predicament that he does not like. In the governments in which I have sat at one time or another I have never known a Minister who has found a refusal of a proposal standing in his or her way. But that Minister is bound to accept the decision of the Cabinet. As I say, this is not a matter of inclination. If one neglects to observe that duty and that principle then one negates it. If one seeks to diminish it one seeks to to nothing else but to destroy it.

Government is not, as some people imagine, a matter of abstract theory. The carrying out of government from day to day and from year to year calls constantly for discipline and the observance of fundamental principles. To be a Minister of the Crown is, I acknowledge, a great honour. But there is a price to be paid for that honour. An individual can have no personal views other than on what friends he will make or, if I may introduce a touch, I trust, of acceptable levity, what horses he will back. He can have no other personal views on anything whatsoever. Being a Minister of the Crown imposes a great burden. It can be a physical burden, it can be a mental burden. It may be a burden to be measured in terms of sheer loneliness or of constant anxiety. But that burden is there. The price further to be paid for it is that at all times that Minister will acknowledge that there is one corporate view. The honour of that office calls for that constantly and for the constant submergence of all personal views. This is not a matter of personal view on my part. I hope that the House will acknowledge the sources of Professor Jennings in his classic work on Cabinet government from which I now wish to quote. He cites what Lord Salisbury said when he stated the principle, as I understand it, to be couched in perfect language. Professor Jennings said in his work:

For all that passes in Cabinet (said Lord Salisbury in 1878) each member of it who does not resign is absolutely and irretrievably responsible, and has no right afterwards to say that he agreed in one case to a compromise, while in another he was persuaded by his colleagues . . . It is only on the principle that absolute responsibility is undertaken by every member of the Cabinet who, after a decision is arrived at, remains a member of it, that the joint responsibility of Ministers to Parliament can be upheld, and one of the most essential principles of parliamentary responsibility established.

I have stated my attitude to the House and to the honourable member for Kooyong. I believe he has erred grievously today. If he had stated one case which he felt had become the catalyst in his resignation, that to me would have been the honourable and the perfect thing to do. But my honourable friend had gone back through the years. I believe that, once having accepted a decision of Cabinet, he is estopped. Forever as he remains in this Parliament he cannot be heard to say: 'No, I disagreed with that. I fought this way; I was in opposition to it'.

We all go through this world having a variety of regrets to life and to what happens. I believe three of the great regrets of life are the spent arrow, the spoken word and the lost opportunity. I do not want to be critical or sententious of my honourable friend, the honourable member for Kooyong. What I have said to him this afternoon has been said by a person who has been, and will seek to remain, his friend. But I would be less than honest if I did not say to the House that I have said it as a friend who has been hurt indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —One would need a heart of stone not to feel compassion for the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) in what he has had to say. He is torn between his personal feelings and innate decency and his compulsion, much of it externally applied, to hold the line for a government for which he feels a sense of duty, mixed with a touch of personal revulsion. The Minister said that people sometimes suffered from phychological burdens and pressures. That was shown in the Minister's face today. The Minister put up a defence to charges that were not made. Like the Minister's predecessors in this debate he has not denied the specific nature of the charges made by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). Let me remind him of what those specific charges were. At one stage he said: 'What is Cabinet if not a co-ordinating committee. The Prime Minister lobbies Ministers before meetings, then there is just a rubber stamp'. 'The collective wisdom', he said, 'is aborted'. 'Where is the collective wisdom', he asked, 'which Malcolm Fraser extolled in 1971?'. He then made perhaps his most important point, something which I have underlined in my notes. He said that Cabinet Ministers are sometimes asked to leave so that the Co-ordinating Committee can meet. Where has there been a denial of that allegation, a most serious allegation, of the breakdown of the principle of Cabinet responsibility? Who has denied it? Did the Prime Minister deny it? Did the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) deny it? Did the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch), deny it? It certainly was not denied by the Minister for Defence. As the honourable member for Kooyong said, it is not just a kitchen cabinet. Individual Ministers are lobbied. There are ad hoc committees of Cabinet which make real decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Between June 1977 and July 1979 of 5,900 Cabinet decisions 1,200 were made by ad hoc committees. Was there any denial of that? No, not at all. The Deputy Prime Minister made the suggestion-I did not copy his exact words but honourable members will recall it-that the Prime Minister had spent a long time, perhaps hours even, agonising with the honourable member for Kooyong, discussing his problems, never denying him the opportunity to speak. That is not exactly what the honourable member for Kooyong said. He indicated that he was desperate to get time with the Prime Minister, that he had begged him for time, that he had been given assurances and that those assurances were not fulfilled. Not even the Prime Minister said that he spent long hours agonising with the honourable member for Kooyong. Knowing the temperament of the two gentlemen involved, one would think it was very unlikely.

The honourable member for Kooyong specifically raised the question about the story of his resignation on the day that the last election was determined. My notes say that the honourable member for Kooyong then went to see the Prime Minister and said that he was in an intolerable position-the United Nations General Assembly was to meet on 15 September and the credentials committee had to decide whether Australia would support the Pol Pot regime or an alternative. The honourable member for Kooyong said the Prime Minister then called in the Deputy Prime Minister, the right Hon. Ian Sinclair, then Minister for Special Trade Representations and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) Mr Peacock suggested three options-a change in policy, resignation, a silence and a refusal of office after the election. As the Prime Minister left to go to see the Governor-General the then Minister for Foreign Affairs agreed not to resign and to keep silent throughout the campaign, to which the Prime Minister replied: 'Thank you, Andrew'. On 14 April the Minister for Primary Industry corroborated this in the office of the honourable member for Kooyong. There was no reference made in earlier speeches about that. Nobody denied it, yet it is absolutely fundamental.

Let us turn for a moment to the specific reason for resignation. That was the question of the Australian leader article of 14 April which said that Andrew Peacock had 'plunged the Government into crisis' before the 1980 election over the issue of Pol Pot and described the then Minister's threat as a 'bombshell'. That, one would think, ought to be denied in detail but nobody so far has talked about the leaks. The Minister for Defence, who has now left the chamber, would well know the latin tag cui bono-who benefits? When we think of the peculiar timing of that leak of 14 April who stood to benefit? Was there any benefit to be gained by the honourable member for Kooyong or was there only a benefit to be gained by the grand leak master himself, the Prime Minister, the greatest exploiter of the Press and the greatest user of the Press that we have had in Australian political history?

Let us go back to the Prime Minister's record. The Prime Minister utterly lacks personal credibility. His assurances simply cannot be believed. His accuracy is in inverse proportion to the vehemence with which he speaks. He is recklessly indifferent to the truth, callous in his attitude to the poor and weak and committed to the philosophy of winning at any cost. He is the most arrogant and most confrontationist Prime Minister in our history. This is the political leader who won supreme power in his own party by the use of the knife. He knifed John Gorton in 1971. He was of little help to the right honourable member for Lowe (Sir William McMahon) in 1972 and 1973. He sandbagged and knifed Sir Billy Snedden, the present Speaker just as he later knifed Sir John Kerr and Reg Withers, both of whom had helped him claw his way to the top. He is the politician who tore up 75 years of constitutional usage in persuading the Senate to block the passage of the Budget. He created a situation in which political stability was to be put at risk every time that one party had a majority in the House of Representatives and another party had a majority in the Senate. In his pragmatic but unprincipled party, the right honourable gentleman has not only survived but also has appeared to prosper for the most pragmatic of all reasons-that he was a winner. He had the killer instinct and after every crunch so far, up to this, he has won. I think that the Government now sees itself in disarray. I believe that before very long the Prime Minister will go. That is not to say the beneficiary will be the honourable member for Kooyong. I think it much more likely that some other figures will emerge.

I want to touch on the speech of the honourable member for Kooyong. There is a fundamental ambiguity in his position. He has not offered a clear alternative philosophy to that of the Prime Minister. It is possible to stitch together a coalition of Liberal members who detest the Prime Minister. But there is no common thread of policy in that coalition. We can get a curious coalition of States' righters, small government men, decentralisers, welfare hardliners, racists, puritans, extreme free marketeers, anti-protectionists and ex-Ministers harbouring personal grudges because of their dismissals. They can be linked together with small 'l' liberals, supporters of a genuine freedom of information legislation, anti-authoritarians, libertarians, the compassionate and those who do not see politics as a blood sport. Both groups have one thing in common-they detest the Prime Minister and they wait and pray daily for the proverbial bus to run over the Prime Minister and to take a few others with him. They detest the style of the Prime Minister but they share nothing else.

The fundamental weakness of the position of the honourable member for Kooyong is that he attempts to fly without the wings and feathers of an ideological position. I comment in passing that the role of the Press has been particularly deplorable in all this. We have had no discussion whatever about ideology, about the fact that there are value systems tied up in the conflict between the Prime Minister and the honourable member for Kooyong. It has been talked entirely in terms of a personality contest. The honourable member for Kooyong is devoid of ideological position or commitment. He is a man for all seasons waiting for a favourable breeze. He lacks the killer instinct of his erstwhile leader. The Prime Minister will be brought down almost certainly within the life of this Parliament but I believe the honourable member for Kooyong will not be the beneficiary. The strongest points in his speech pointed to the Prime Minister's authoritarian methodology. There he was on very much stronger ground.

I go back to the role of the Prime Minister as a manipulator. The Prime Minister has always used every instrument that he could to destroy his enemies. I believe that he has done an effective job in destroying the honourable member for Kooyong because he would have seen the honourable member for Kooyong as the only alternative with significant public support. It is clear that, at the moment, the Government is so preoccupied with matters of personality that it has completely lost sense of its priority, the introduction of legislation. Has there every been, Mr Deputy Speaker, in your political experience, a time when the Notice Paper has been so threadbare? I think that at the moment there are only four Bills, all in my area of interest, on the Notice Paper. Debates on a number of Government statements have been adjourned. They are yet to be dealt with. We are still waiting for the rush of legislation. The problem is, of course, that there is too much bitter division within the Government parties to reach agreement on legislation.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me restate the point I was making at high speed before the suspension of the sitting for dinner. The main point made by the honourable member for Kooyong in his speech this afternoon explaining his resignation as Minister for Industrial Relations was his attack on the methodology of the Prime Minister in running his Government. The Prime Minister, it is alleged, has eroded the Cabinet system by destroying the concept of collective responsibility within the Cabinet and undermining the constitutional relationship between Cabinet and this Parliament. The honourable member for Kooyong gave specific details of this in quite a long speech-it lasted 53 minutes-and his accusations have simply not been answered. The Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister for Industry and Commerce have tried a very broad-brush defence. They have done this by completely evading the specific issues raised. Instead they have painted a completely unconvincing picture of the Prime Minister as a warm, approachable character who likes nothing more than a good long chat to reconcile differences of opinion between his Ministers. As I recall, the Minister for Industry and Commerce had exactly the same opinion of the Prime Minister on this subject as the honourable member for Kooyong in November 1977. One has only to state the proposition to recognise its palpable absurdity.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been no specific reply to the points made by the honourable member for Kooyong. The differences in style and methodology between the Prime Minister and the honourable member for Kooyong are very great. One has a closed mind, the other has an open mind. One is distant, remote, hard to talk to and resistant to new ideas, except those of an authoritarian nature. The other is affable, approachable, easy to talk to and open to new ideas. One would look good in a uniform; the other looks good in anything. The key difference is this: The Prime Minister is a great advocate of the anti-concensus style in politics. He destroyed Billy Snedden who was a practitioner of concensus. He won office in 1975 by overturning the conventional wisdom of Australian politics which had developed throughout the Menzies era and lasted, with some variations, until 1975. His anti-concensus style which became electorally popular in the mid-1970s was followed also by Robert Muldoon, Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan. It has inflicted great harm on the fragile concensus on which the parliamentary system rests in Australia, New Zealand and Great Britain. I fear that it will lead to horrendous social division in the United States. The Prime Minister has applied his anti-concensus style with a notable lack of success in the field of industrial relations. That is essentially why the honourable member for Kooyong had to go. Australia is no longer a parliamentary democracy in the strict sense; it is really a bucolocracy ruled by graziers.

In that amazing Co-ordination Committee of the Cabinet there are five Ministers. Of those five Ministers two are members of the National Country Party. The Prime Minister is himself a de facto supporter of rural interests as against urban interests. The tragedy of the honourable member for Kooyong was that he was the most credible representative in the Cabinet of urban liberal interests. That is why he had to go. The Prime Minister will not change in style. It would be like expecting a crocodile to turn vegetarian.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I turn to the substance of the censure motion I want to clarify several points relating to my part in events, particularly those points relating to the story which appeared in the Australian on the Pol Pot issue. I do this with some sadness because I have been closely associated with the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock)-I regret that he is not in the House-over a number of issues and events and believe there is a bond of friendship and trust between us. I stress that the relationship in any dealings that I have had with the honourable member for Kooyong has not been because I have been a member of any particular party but because of that relationship. At page 10 of the statement of the honourable member for Kooyong to the Parliament he said:

SPEECH.PARA: At my request, conveyed to the Prime Minister through three ministerial colleagues who came to discuss this report with me, the Prime Minister agreed that he would issue a denial. Later, the Prime Minister deputed the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) to show me the form of his so-called denial. These are its full and complete terms:
I have seen the statement on the front of today's Australian concerning events that occurred last year. There are some significant inaccuracies in that report.

I was appalled when I saw its bareness and I said so to the Minister for Primary Industry. It scarcely could bear the description of a denial. It did not even deign to express which allegations were denied. For all the reader was to know, it might have been a denial of the allegations in the report that there had been a so-called bitter six month feud or that there was a battle for the leadership of the parliamentary Liberal Party. When I made this point to the Minister--
That is, me-
he said:
Any inadequacies are not for you to be concerned about. They are matters that the Prime Minister or Barnett will background on.

That is not an accurate account of the events. The words in the denial were the words asked for by the honourable member for Kooyong and written down by me in longhand. I, along with the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) and the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), who have confirmed this, conveyed those words to the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). The Prime Minister agreed quickly to the use of those words. The Minister for Defence and the Minister for Finance have confirmed with me tonight that they returned with me to Mr Peacock's office. It was the Minister for Finance who said to the honourable member for Kooyong: 'You have got the words that you wanted'. After some further discussion, in the presence of the Minister for Finance and the Minister for Defence, the honourable member for Kooyong agreed that he had got the words that he wanted. Those words were: 'There are some significant inaccuracies in that report'. They were the key words that he wanted. The Press statement was not issued until later in the afternoon. I carried it to Mr Peacock's office without the other two Ministers. I will quote from some notes that I made following my visit to Mr Peacock's office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will refer to the honourable member for Kooyong.

—These are the notes I made following my visit to the office of the honourable member for Kooyong. I cannot refer to him as the honourable member for Kooyong because that is not how I referred to him in my notes. My notes state:

SPEECH.PARA: Peacock bridled at the lack of information and detail on the statement, saying the statement did not refer to him by name, nor to the particular article on the front page of the Australian. I pointed out that the statement carried the substance of the words that he had requested of Guilfoyle, Killen and myself to obtain--
He had agreed to these words earlier in the day-
and that was that there were some significant inaccuracies in the report.

Peacock had accepted that aspect of the report as satisfactory but he expressed concern about the lack of other matters relating to the report. I said if there are any inadequacies in the statement in terms of his name being missing and direct reference to the article or any other matters, that was a matter for the Prime Minister or David Barnett to explain.

The honourable member for Kooyong wanted and had agreed to the words that were typed up in the formal Press statement and were issued later in the day. Later I heard Press reports to the effect that the honourable member for Kooyong was claiming that undertakings were not being honoured. On the Wednesday I visited the office of the honourable member for Kooyong and I spoke to him about these reported claims. Again I made a record of the conversation. I shall read it to the Parliament. It states:

Today I visited Andrew Peacock and sought clarification about his statement at his Press conference 'that there is a whole series of events and there were some undertakings given yesterday which were broken.'

I asked Peacock if in any way he thought I was associated with broken undertakings, pointing out that as far as I was concerned the only undertaking was to get the Prime Minister to publicly state that there were serious discrepancies in the report referring to the story on Pol Pot in the Australian on Monday.

Peacock raised the question of briefing by Barnett and I said to him that I had said in the discussion yesterday that 'any shortcomings in the statement are not a matter for you to be concerned about.' You have got the words you wanted.
Let me repeat that:

You have got the words you wanted. Any shortcomings are a matter for the Prime Minister and Barnett to answer for.'' I did not suggest that there would be background briefings. Peacock wrote those words down and indicated that he accepted entirely my explanation of the events. He went on to say that I was not party to any undertakings that were broken.

Not only did the Minister for Defence, the Minister for Finance and I disagree with the honourable member for Kooyong on the words used but also it is apparent from today's statement that the view of the honourable member for Kooyong on the reason for his resignation is now different from the reasons he gave at his Press conference on 15 April. In that Press conference he was asked, concerning undertakings:
Were they broken in the statement issued by the Prime Minister yesterday?
He answered:
The statement issued by the Prime Minister yesterday was surprisingly vague.
The next question was:
Do you consider that unsatisfactory?
He answered:
Well I indicated that I hoped there would be further explanations given. Evidently there weren't.

The undertaking the honourable member for Kooyong appeared to be concerned about seemed to relate to the Nationwide program. This was borne out by what Mr Simon said on PM on 15 April following this question from Nasht:
What were those events that prompted the final action?
Mr Simon replied:

Well, as I understand it, there were certain undertakings given yesterday which by the time last evening came, and one particular television program clearly indicated that that undertaking had been broken, where discussions were to take place in regard to an allegation that Mr Lynch's office, or Mr Lynch himself, had been involved in the release of the Pol Pot story to the Australian yesterday morning, and that undertaking was clearly broken and the Minister sought clarification from the Prime Minister last night, was unable to obtain that clarification and after a great deal of thought, and I know anguish, he felt he had to resign, that this was the last straw.
That was confirmed also by the honourable member for Kooyong himself on Nationwide on 15 April, when he said:
There was an undertaking in regard to your own program last night which was broken so far as I am concerned.

This reason-that is the reason given on Nationwide-was also widely accepted as the reason by wide sections of the media. Michelle Gratten had the story in the Melbourne Age of 16 April; it was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald, the Sun Pictorial and the Australian Financial Review of the same date; and Paul Kelly had the story in the Sydney Morning Herald of 17 April. All those newspapers carried the story of the Nationwide program being the central issue for the honourable member for Kooyong.
Let me turn now to the options about which the honourable member for Kooyong has spoken. He said he gave three options to the Prime Minister in the Prime Minister's office. The first was:
I could resign.
The second was:
. . . the Cabinet could change its policy.
The third was:
. . . in the event that the Government did not change the policy, I could remain silent until after the election and then decline a portfolio in a new Government.

I can-I did on 14 April-corroborate for the honourable member for Kooyong that he gave those three options on 11 September. I corroborated that in the presence of the Ministers for Defence and the Minister for Finance. But the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Finance, who were present, and I do not remember the words 'Thank you, Andrew' coming into the conversation. But whether the Prime Minister did in fact say 'Thank you, Andrew' is irrelevant. The fact is that the conversations that I had with the honourable member for Kooyong on the night of 11 September continued for hours and final agreement on the handling of the Pol Pot matter was not reached until 11 o'clock that night, some five and a half to six hours after the Prime Minister had been to and returned from Government House.

As far as the options are concerned, the truth of the matter is that option one was a gun at the head of the Government; option 2 was also a gun at the head of the Government; and option 3 was not accepted as a real option by anybody present in the room because the Government was about to go to the country at a general election and, if the story that Mr Peacock would not accept a portfolio in a new government had broken, it could have brought down the Government. It was because each of the options proposed by the honourable member for Kooyong was impossible that I spent hours that night getting agreement on words that would satisfy the honourable member for Kooyong to be used after the credentials vote was taken in the United Nations. That agreement was not reached until 11 p.m. on the night of 11 September. Therefore, it is clearly not correct for the honourable member for Kooyong to claim, as he did this evening on PM, that the question of his three options on the Pol Pot issue clarified the matter before the Prime Minister went to Government House. The Prime Minister put the agreed formal words on the Democratic Kampuchea problem to Cabinet in Melbourne on 23 September-it had been agreed that it would go to the next Cabinet meeting-and Cabinet agreed to the words used. At this point Mr Peacock was in fact at the United Nations awaiting, he hoped, the credentials vote in the United Nations.

I hope that puts to rest once and for all the claims and counter-claims that have been made in this matter. I have been central to this issue. I am sorry to have had to come into this House and disclose what I thought were private conversations leading to sensible agreements. I have done so because it was the honourable member for Kooyong who first broached the issues that drew me into the Parliament tonight. That is all I have to say on those matters. I have nothing to add to what Ministers have said today that so devastatingly kills the Opposition's censure motion on this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — We have just listened to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) invite the House to make, presumably, a judgment as to which member of the Cabinet or former member of the Cabinet we are to believe-which one is telling the truth. He then dismissed the entire substance of the Opposition's censure motion. Let us get back to the heart of the very serious allegations made by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). The first was that under this Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) power has become dangerously centralised and the concept of Cabinet government has been eroded. He stated that this process has been developed by the Prime Minister's use of his Department and by the use of the co-ordinating committee, a committee which carries out the Prime Minister's dictates.

SPEECH.PARA: The first question that we have to ask ourselves is: Is this a fact? Is there such a body as the co-ordinating committee? That of course is admitted. It has not been denied by the Prime Minister or any other Minister. We heard a sterling defence by the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen), who claimed to be a friend of the honourable member for Kooyong and then proceeded to shaft him. But all the sterling defences in the world about the concept of Cabinet government do not meet the very serious allegation of the honourable member for Kooyong, who stated that the Prime Minister at a Cabinet meeting-I ask the House to consider this as a concept of responsible Cabinet government in 1981 under Malcolm Fraser-will direct a member of Cabinet to leave the Cabinet room so that the Co-ordination Committee can make a decision in his absence. That has to be a truly novel concept of Cabinet government.

TALK.START.PARA: —And not denied by anyone.

—Of course no one-neither the Prime Minister nor any Minister who has spoken-has denied the accuracy of that statement. Who are the presiding geniuses-Australia's very own gang of five-who make up this co-ordinating committee? Of course, there is the Prime Minister, the Minister for Trade and Resources, Mr Anthony, the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Sir Phillip Lynch, the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, the Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair, and the Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Carrick. Not even their best friends would say that that was a committee noted for its intellectual depths. I ask the House to consider this incredible concept of Cabinet government. The Prime Minister says to Peacock or to the Treasurer (Mr Howard), or some other responsible Minister with whose views he does not agree: 'It is time for you to leave now John. The Co-ordinating Committee when you are outside the door will solve this problem'. We have this extraordinary collection of squatters. Three of them are squatters, one a resurrected undertaker.
—He has still got some stolen money.
—I do not make that assertion.
—Order! I ask the honourable member for Fremantle to withdraw his remark.
—I withdraw.

—The honourable knight for Stumpy Gully has had a hand in all of this, and then of course there is Senator Carrick. Everybody knows that when the Prime Minister sniffs, Senator Carrick blows his nose. This is the group that, by its every existence, imports a concept of servility into the whole concept of Cabinet government. Unless that is answered, it must prove the honourable member for Kooyong's very serious allegation that the concept of Cabinet government is being eroded under this Prime Minister. It is an odd and perverse situation indeed that even the Minister for Defence, with his rhetoric could argue that this odd and novel Fraserism represents any concept which is within the framework of the Westminster tradition.

SPEECH.PARA: Suppose honourable members opposite were to go to any high school in Australia and be asked who is the Minister responsible to the Parliament for industrial relations. That is the concept under the Westminster system that the Minister is part of a Cabinet but in administering his portfolio he is responsible to the Parliament and through the Parliament to the people of Australia. The somewhat naive gentlemen opposite would answer that, of course, everyone knows that the Minister for Industrial Relations is responsible to the Parliament for the formulation and the expression of the Government's attitude on important industrial issues. But, what does the honourable member for Kooyong say? What does this former important spokesman for the Liberal Party-he was recognised as such within his own State and within this Parliament-say? He says that on not fewer than three major items-wages policy, the Qantas Airways Ltd dispute and the 35-hour week-the Co-ordinating Committee, the gang of five, met and formulated policy without even his involvement. So, the views of the then Minister and the expertise that existed within his Department, and the capacity and knowledge that go with that, were all swept aside because of this motley group who are concerned to centralise power around the Prime Minister. If ever the Prime Minister accepts a knighthood, the stiletto ought to be the central part of his coat of arms-the regalia that he wears.

Everyone knows of the enlightened views, the tolerance and the judgment of the Prime Minister and his cohorts in the National Country Party on industrial affairs. It is these men who formulated the attitude that was put to this House in regard to the 35-hour week. What nonsense they spoke. Of course, it was interesting that the former Minister was not very anxious to get closely involved in that debate. In relation to wages policy, the honourable member for Kooyong said there was a Cabinet decision which, after it had been checked and verified through the processes of his party, he put public. Within a matter of days, the Prime Minister had walked away from that decision and had adopted a policy of industrial confrontation directed at any employer in this country who disagreed with his somewhat narrow and novel views.

In regard to the defence and maintenance of the Cabinet system of government, the Prime Minister, nor any Minister, has denied the substantive allegation of the former Minister, the man who was elected and who swore an oath to be responsible ultimately to this Parliament in the terms of his portfolio. What did the then Minister do? What could he do when he saw that in these areas in which he had sworn to accept his responsibilities as a Cabinet Minister he could not uphold those responsibilities to this Parliament and that the operations of his Department were being continually eroded, contrary to the concept of responsible Cabinet government, by the actions of the Prime Minister and his gang of five? What could he do? I cannot judge the Minister for Primary Industry, who wants to swear one set of allegations against the detail of what has been said by the honourable member for Kooyong. All that we on this side of the House can say is that none of us were there; we were not privy to the conversation. Even with the best will in the world we cannot honestly tell which Liberal or which member of the National Country Party is telling the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —None of them are Catholics.

—That compounds the problem, I admit. They are not even unfinancial Catholics. We on this side of the House believe that the honourable member for Kooyong has been just a little bit naive in believing that the Prime Minister would keep his word to him. After all, why should the Prime Minister keep his word to any Minister? It is a public fact that he has never kept his word to the people of Australia on the election promises he has made. He has walked away from every political undertaking he has given. The Speaker of this House was prepared to speak for all the members of his Party, including the present Prime Minister, when he said to the people of Australia that they would follow him through the valley of death.
—They would walk over hot coals.

—And walk over hot coals. Anybody who wanted to lead the Prime Minister over hot coals into the valley of death will be found limp and corpse-like with a glazed look upon his face. That is the man's reputation. In clawing his way to leadership in Australia he has helped successfully to plant the knife in two leaders. He dragged the very constitutional structures of this nation and our constitutional conventions into the direst crisis that the people of Australia have ever seen. He is confrontationist by nature. Do we wonder when we see the Prime Minister cast his gaze upon those Ministers and tap them on the shoulder and say: 'Now get up and let us see where you stand, whether you support me or the honourable member for Kooyong'? All on this side of the House have seen the somewhat disgusting spectacle of all these Ministers getting up and saying: 'He was a friend of mine. I loved him well, and I will still love him. But I am bound to tell this House that my fear of the Prime Minister transcends all'. There has been no greater performance since Brutus slipped the knife into Julius Caesar than the performance we saw from the Minister for Defence tonight. Et tu, Jim!

SPEECH.PARA: The sadness of this spectacle is that whatever might be said about the honourable member for Kooyong by some of his former Cabinet colleagues, the opinion polls seem to suggest that he has a much higher standing in the electorate than does the Prime Minister. Although he may be feeling a little bruised and battered tonight he can rest safe in the knowledge that at the moment when the spectre of losing office confronts some of his former colleagues they will shaft this Prime Minister, come to him and say: 'All is forgiven.' In the meantime the damage that has been done to this institution and to the concept of Cabinet government is irreparable. The only honourable course for this House is to pass this censure motion, condemn this Prime Minister and his ways and give this nation a leadership which at least has some integrity and honour and which is able to say to the people of Australia that the Parliament of this nation will not again be subjected to the spectacle to which we have all had to be witness today. Honourable members can make up their minds whether they want to believe the Prime Minister, members of Cabinet or the honourable member who had to put in his resignation in disgust because he could no longer suffer the indignities and injustices which have now befallen the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not an easy motion for any person to speak on from this side of the House. Perhaps one of the most ungracious contributions of the whole debate was the closing portion of the remarks made by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding). By implication and by use of those immortal words 'Et tu'-he substituted the name 'Jim'-he impugned the sincerity of the remarks made earlier this evening by the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen). I have not known a more honourable person in this House than the Minister for Defence, the honourable member for Moreton. I think it is very regrettable that the honourable member for Melbourne Ports should have injected that note into his remarks. It is, of course, a matter of regret for any government that a senior Minister should resign. It damages that government. I do not believe for a moment, nor I imagine do any of my colleagues, that the events of the past two weeks have not been of significant damage to the cause of the Liberal Party and the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had a very lengthy debate today. We have canvassed in great detail the events of last year surrounding the policy of the Government towards the recognition of the Pol Pot regime in Kampuchea. We have also debated the events of the last two or three weeks leading to the resignation of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). I have not been as directly connected with some of those events as have some of my colleagues who have spoken previously. Therefore, I cannot speak with personal knowledge of the detail of the discussions and exchanges. Therefore, I shall confine myself to making a few general observations about the operation of the Cabinet system of government which has been a focal point of the remarks not only of my former colleague, the honourable member for Kooyong, but also of the Opposition and other Government speakers. Unlike other Ministers who have spoken in this debate, my experience of the Cabinet system of government is limited to service under the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) over the last five and a half years. I can say only that the degree of consultation, the number of meetings, the inordinate lengths that are gone to to ensure that people are consulted and informed in the decision-making process is, on my experience, very extensive and wide. I am sorry to have to say, in deference to what my former colleague said in his speech, that as a Cabinet Minister for the past three years I cannot recall one occasion on which I have been ordered out of the room so that a meeting of the Co-ordination Committee could take place.

As anybody who knows about the operation of a Cabinet system will realise, full Cabinet meetings are often followed by meetings of other Cabinet committees. Indeed, in the nature of the operation of Cabinet business there is nothing particularly unusual about that. In my experience the level of consultation and the degree of debate and disagreement inside the Cabinet have been extremely intense and wide. By and large, I believe the Cabinet system has operated very effectively and in accordance with what I understand to be the proper principles of Westminster government. According to my recollection, the Co-ordination Committee was established in 1978 or early 1979 out of a concern about earlier criticism that arrangements for consultation between senior Ministers were too informal and, therefore, too open to criticism. In other words, it was designed to answer concern at that time that there was not formal machinery for senior Ministers to consult about broad government strategy. It is therefore ironic that it should be criticised as a method of focusing power inside the Government.

What is most important and what really matters about this debate is not so much the events of the past few weeks but, rather, what the censure motion is all about. It is a motion expressing want of confidence in the Prime Minister. Although it is important to make a finite judgment about every single thing that has been said about the events of the past few weeks, perhaps the best test of whether this House should express confidence in the Prime Minister is to make a judgment on the stewardship of the Prime Minister and the Government over the last five and a half years. I invite honourable members to ask themselves whether the record of this Government over the last five and a half years and the potential of this Government and in particular of the Liberal Party of Australia to solve the challenges of this country for the remainder of this decade is either the record or the potential of a government and a party that should be condemned. It is increasingly becoming a matter of accepted fact that the economic policies of this Government have worked in a way quite beyond the expectations even of some of the more enthusiastic supporters of those policies only a few years ago.

In this context I am reminded of all the things that have been said by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) when he was campaigning in the McPherson by-election, about the economic policies of this Government. The Opposition said that the Budget which was brought down in 1978 would drive the economy through the floor. It said the same thing about the 1979 Budget. These criticisms have been voiced about the sorts of economic policies that have been followed by the Government led by the present Prime Minister over the last five and a half years. Of course, the truth is that those policies have borne fruit. The essential Liberal principles to which we committed ourselves in 1975 by and large have been adhered to-with some deviation, I confess-over the last five and a half years. If they are adhered to with renewed vigour over the remainder of this term of office, the Government will be returned again as it has been on three earlier occasions.

The level of economic growth in Australia at present is far beyond the expectation that we entertained when the Budget was brought down last August. Australia is one of the few countries in the industrialised world at the moment which is experiencing real economic growth. Does that show the performance of a government whose leader should be censured? Does that show the performance of a government that deserves the condemnation of this House? It shows the performance of a government which has very much delivered the goods that it promised when it was elected in 1975. We have seen not only economic growth but also a sustained growth in overall employment in this country over a period of two years. We have seen this country go from a nation that was seen as an uncertain recipient of overseas investment to a country which is increasingly seen as having a stable and predictable economic climate in which to invest. That is a creature, not of uncertain leadership, not of hesitant decision making, but of sound, sensible and stable leadership. It is not a creature of a government that deserves censure. It is not the outcome of the leadership of a person who deserves to be censured by this House at this time.

I do not pretend for a moment that the economic and other problems of this country will be solved automatically over the next few years. I do not pretend that the great wealth that this country has, particularly in the resource area, will be realised unless we adopt sensible and sensitive policies. The problems will not be solved unless we recognise that it is impossible at one and the same time to finance the growing demands of a private sector and an expanding public sector. Unlike those opposite, I do not believe that it is possible for us to have the growth in development that we would like to have in this country unless we are prepared to rein in the avaricious demands of all levels of government in our community. More than ever, the economic circumstances of Australia at present demand more and not less of the essential economic philosophy of the Liberal Party.

I hope that, beginning this week with the announcement of the review of Commonwealth functions by the Prime Minister, we will see a re-assertion of the essential economic faith of the Liberal Party, which is about small government, about reducing the demands of government on the community's resources and about making way for the expansion and the activity of the private sector. I believe this House and the Australian people expect from this Government a continuation of the sort of stability that has produced not only the gains in economic conditions throughout Australia but also those other social gains of which the Prime Minister spoke in his remarks earlier.
