TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Last week I announced that all people entering Australia will be required to carry a passport as from 1 July 1981. The measure is intended to curb abuses of the existing Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement. It is not aimed at restricting the right of Australian and New Zealand citizens to visit or to settle either permanently or temporarily in the other country; it is aimed primarily at those foreigners who pose as Australian or New Zealand citizens. At the same time I indicated that, consistent with our special trans-Tasman relationship, Australia wished to maintain a special status for New Zealanders. The new measures will preserve a uniquely privileged position for New Zealanders in Australia's immigration policies by allowing them to come to Australia without visas and to remain here without entry permits. The existing arrangement provides that people who are citizens of Australia and New Zealand and those who are citizens of other Commonwealth countries or of the Republic of Ireland with resident status in Australia or New Zealand may travel directly between the two countries without either passport or visa.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been concern in Australia for some time about the susceptibility of the arrangement to abuse. This led to official talks in 1974 and to a visit to New Zealand by the then Minister for Labour and Immigration in 1975, seeking the introduction of a requirement that all trans-Tasman passengers carry a travel document. Whilst this was not proceeded with at that time there have been further talks at ministerial and official levels on this matter. New Zealand has visa abolition agreements with some 21 countries. As a result, nationals of those countries may travel to New Zealand without prior screening. This severely limits New Zealand's capacity to prevent the entry of undesirable individuals. Once in New Zealand, any person can exploit the trans-Tasman arrangement by simply buying a ticket in an assumed name and claiming on arrival in Australia to be a New Zealand or Australian citizen or a citizen of a Commonwealth country or the Republic of Ireland with resident status in New Zealand or Australia. Officers controlling entry at airports are under considerable pressure to process passengers quickly and are unable in most cases to challenge the validity of such claims in the limited time available. Moreover, Australia has such a multiracial society that persons challenged may well be Australian citizens. In those circumstances challenge and interrogation could cause great offence.

In the report of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs, Mr Justice Williams drew attention to the evidence of abuse of the Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement by the illegal drug trade and recommended the introduction of a passport requirement for such travel. It is known that members of several terrorist organisations are aware that it is much easier to circumvent Australia's normal stringent safeguards against the entry of terrorists by entry from New Zealand than by attempting use of fake documentation or other means of direct entry. Australian and New Zealand criminals have taken advantage of trans-Tasman travel both to escape justice in their own country and to find new fields to exploit in the other. New Zealanders now constitute half of the criminal deportees from Australia. Some of the New Zealand criminals have been deported from Australia several times, having returned to Australia under yet another false name after each deportation.

People abducting children from Australia have also exploited the Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement. Whilst there are measures to prevent the removal from Australia of abducted children, these depend on the children being taken from this country under their own name. The ease with which new identities can be assumed for the purpose of Trans-Tasman Travel allows the established controls to be by-passed simply by claiming to be travellers to New Zealand. This is an era of fast and relatively cheap international air travel when residence in Australia is sought by many more people than can be accepted in our normal immigration program. There has been evidence in information provided by deportees and most recently by the Regularisation of Status Program applicants of entry from New Zealand to circumvent Australia's migrant entry controls.

There are important differences between the Australian and New Zealand policies and procedures. Whereas Australia has a comprehensive visa screening system, New Zealand has agreements with 21 countries providing for certain types of visa-free travel. Whereas Australia has a computerised entry control screening system, New Zealand is still in the process of developing one and it will take a minimum of 12 months to be in operation. Whereas Australia has a non-discriminatory immigration policy, New Zealand wishes to continue to give preferential treatment to certain traditional source countries. In the interests of both overcoming the Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement abuses and-(Quorum formed). I am indebted to the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) for calling a quorum. It was his predecessor who was exceptionally concerned with this subject. I am delighted he is so concerned also. I was referring to the importance of overcoming the abuses to the Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement and at the same time extending the special relationship between the two countries. In the interests of doing that, last month Australia proposed to New Zealand the adoption of common entry, screening and control policies and procedures. This would have meant that all persons entering New Zealand would automatically have gone through the same procedures as those employed by Australia for screening of undesirables. I would have thought that this was a reasonable proposition to put. But this proposal was rejected by the New Zealand Prime Minister in a letter to the Australian Prime Minister (Mr Fraser). Despite that, when I was in New Zealand shortly afterwards I held extensive talks with my New Zealand counterpart both with and without officials. It became obvious that those policies and procedures could not be harmonised.

Ministers and officials have also examined other options for overcoming abuses. Some foreign governments and representatives of some ethnic groups in Australia have argued that, since Australia has a non-discriminatory migration policy, people entering from New Zealand should be on the same footing as people travelling from all other countries. Under this approach, New Zealand citizens would need to undergo the tests of Australia's migration, temporary residence or visitor criteria to obtain a visa in a passport for travel to Australia. They would then have to obtain an entry permit on arrival. The Government considers that such an approach would be inconsistent with Australia's wish to maintain a special provision for New Zealanders in Australia's entry policies, reflecting the special fraternal trans-Tasman relationship.

Surveys of passengers arriving from New Zealand in the past six weeks have shown that the proportion without any identification whatsoever on their persons or in their baggage varied between 7 per cent and 12 per cent. This was con- firmed by baggage examination. Translated to the total of trans-Tasman movements, that would mean that between 30,000 passengers and 50,000 passengers had absolutely no identification on arrival in Australia. In addition, 30 per cent of passengers surveyed had no authoritative identification such as passports or driving licences.

Another option would have been to step up the questioning and baggage search of all persons arriving from New Zealand without authoritative identification-that is, about 70 per cent of those travelling. As the above figures indicate, this would involve a large proportion of the total trans-Tasman travellers. Those unable to provide satisfactory evidence of their claimed identity or entitlement to free entry to Australia would face the prospect of being refused entry. Such an approach would inevitably penalise some innocent people and impose on carriers the cost and inconvenience of returning people to New Zealand. The remaining significant option was to introduce a passport requirement. This in fact was the only feasible step with any prospect of overcoming the major abuses of the Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement and has been adopted for implementation as from 1 July 1981.

It has been suggested by some people that this measure will be ineffective as terrorists and professional criminals can readily obtain false or altered passports for entry. It is true that such people have shown that they can obtain false documentation. I have acknowledged previously that passports alone will not eliminate all of the serious abuses. Nevertheless it is the professional judgment of security and police authorities that a secure form of identity documentation such as a passport adds to the security of the entry system. This is especially true now that our authorities have introduced security materials, the use of which will make passports increasingly difficult to falsify and which are progressively introducing systems which will more readily detect attempted falsifications.

For the less professional operators, the inconvenience and the difficulty of having to obtain false documentation are deterrents. A much greater deterrent is the fact that authorities have information networks which produce intelligence on the purchase, preparation and use of false documents and this significantly increases the probability of detection. Another factor is that, under the present arrangement, people are not subjected to any restriction at all on the number of aliases which they can use for clandestine trans-Tasman travel. At least with a passport requirement, they are limited in the number of passports which they may carry and the very fact of possession of two or more passports in different names, if discovered, would normally lead to the apprehension and expulsion of undesirables using multiple documentation. Thus, the passport requirement is not being introduced in isolation. It will have some effect in itself and it will complement other measures now being taken. The additional protection for Australian society is ample justification for its introduction. I might add that the European Economic Community has reviewed its procedures for travel between member countries. Despite the strengthening of economic and political links within the Community it decided to retain an identity document requirement but it elected to use a card rather than have a full passport. What is important to note is that the European Economic Community did not believe that it was appropriate to abolish documentation.

There have been suggestions from time to time that an identity card might be preferable to a passport as a means of identifying Australian and New Zealand citizens travelling across the Tasman. This proposal has the attractions of cheapness and simplicity. However, it also has its shortcomings. Australia has already established procedures for passport issue and recent steps to make the passport much more secure than a normal identity card. Unlike the passport, the identity card makes no provision for details of previous international travel-data of considerable importance to security, narcotics control and police authorities generally. One further consideration is that in officials' discussions, New Zealand has made it clear that if an identity document requirement were to be introduced for trans-Tasman travel-it has always opposed this-New Zealand would strongly prefer that to be a passport.

It has been suggested that the introduction of a passport requirement would seriously reduce the flow of tourists between Australia and New Zealand. Those who make this assertion are unable to provide any evidence to back it up. In fact the passport represents only a very small part of the total cost of an overseas visit, including a visit to New Zealand, and it remains valid for all overseas travel for a period of five years. In discussions on this matter, representatives of Qantas Airways Ltd, which has a very substantial share of the market across the Tasman, have affirmed that the introduction of a travel document would not reduce Qantas's business on the trans-Tasman route.

There has been a suggestion also that Australia's action was hasty. I ask the House to consider the facts. More than six years ago, the then Australian Minister and Australian officials informed their New Zealand counterparts of Australia's concern at abuses of the Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement and the then Minister for Labor and Immigration sought measures to close the loopholes. There have been Ministers' and officials' discussions on the matter in 1978, 1979 and 1980. At the conclusion of ministerial discussions in April 1980, my New Zealand counterpart and I issued a joint communique announcing that we would consider the matter further at the next scheduled ministerial conference. That conference took place earlier this month in Wellington. Some weeks before it, Cabinet determined what the Australian negotiating position should be and this was relayed to the New Zealand Government by my colleague the Honourable Tony Street on 27 March 1981.

It has also been contended in the past few days that the passport requirement will be prejudicial to the close trans-Tasman relationship. It seems to be forgotten that passports are primarily a means of identification. Australian citizens have had to carry passports to identify themselves as Australian citizens entitled to entry to Australia without permits on returning to Australia from all places except New Zealand. I am sure that the relationship with New Zealand will not be jeopardised by a requirement that Australians and New Zealanders identify themselves as such on entry to Australia. On the other hand, the abuse of the Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement and the broad potential for abuse have been irritants in relations between the two countries. Action to overcome abuses should help eliminate such irritants. The passport requirement by itself maintains the special privilege for New Zealanders and ensures ready entry for all except the dishonest. It is our assessment that it will facilitate and speed up entry at Australian airports after initial transitional teething troubles are overcome.

One other feature of the Australian Government decision is to limit the Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement to persons who are citizens of Australia or New Zealand. The existing provision for certain other residents of both countries reflected the fact that Australia's immigration policies and New Zealand's immigration policies previously contained a special preferment for citizens of the Commonwealth and Ireland. When Australia finally eliminated that form of discrimination in 1973, in regard to people entering from all other countries, it did not take action to amend the Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement in the same way. This step is overdue, given the firm public commitment to a non-discriminatory policy which treats all of its migrant communities on an equal footing.

In the field of immigration and international travel, there is very close co-operation between the two countries. Australia has been giving New Zealand the benefit of its knowledge and experience on technical aspects of tightening up entry arrangements and there has been regular consultation at both ministerial and official level on a wide range of other aspects of migration and migrant settlement.

In his statement last Friday, the Right Honourable Duncan MacIntyre, Acting Prime Minister of New Zealand, reiterated that Australia's decision did not affect the essential feature of the Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement. By this, he was referring to the free access of New Zealanders and Australians to each other's country. Mr MacIntyre went on to describe the special relationship and the free travel as: 'the mark of a special relationship between Australia and New Zealand which the Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement represents'. Mr MacIntyre also expressed his confidence that the current close co-operation between Australia and New Zealand on immigration and security matters would continue and further help to ensure 'that the possibilities of abuse of our respective rights and privileges of entry are reduced still further'.

This statement, which I commend to honourable members, seems to take due account of the fact that all Australia has done is to ask that citizens of Australia and New Zealand travelling freely between the two countries take steps to identify themselves in a reliable and internationally acceptable manner. It is worth noting that Mr MacIntyre's constructive, understanding response has been echoed by the President of the New Zealand Chamber of Commerce, Mr S. R. Hull, who issued a statement last Sunday. Mr Hull stressed the value of a passport to travellers not only in facilitating their travel but also as a means of identifying themselves for a variety of other purposes. Mr Hull went on to say:

The disaster at Munich is still fresh in our minds and I believe the commercial community would accept the necessity for carrying documentation when visiting Australia if it helped to prevent a disruption of the Commonwealth Games or any other activity. Further, I believe documentation between Australia and New Zealand would facilitate the freedom of entry for bona fide New Zealand travellers rather than frustrate it.

Finally, I would like to reaffirm several points in the hope that current misunderstandings of the Government's decision can be dispelled. First, whilst the new measures will not eliminate all entry to Australia by undesirables, they will substantially reduce it. Second, Australia continues to welcome free trans-Tasman movement of New Zealand citizens and the passport requirement will not impede their entry apart from that of a small proportion of criminals. I might add that residents of the Cook Islands and Niue, as New Zealand citizens, have the same right of entry as other New Zealanders. Third, while the new measures preserve a special place for Australian and New Zealand citizens, they eliminate current differences in treatment between migrant groups on the basis of their nationality. Fourth, Australia looks forward to continuing close co-operation with New Zealand in the field of immigration as well as in other aspects of the relationship.

I hope that the new approach will be seen for what it is. It is a set of measures which preserve the special relationship with New Zealand; which eliminate a discriminatory element from the former approach; which close loopholes open to exploitation by people who pose a threat to Australian society; and also which facilitate the entry of the vast majority of trans-Tasman travellers. I commend the approach to honourable members. I present the following paper:
Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement-Ministerial statement, 28 April 1981.

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Port Adelaide speaking for a period not exceeding 23 minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition treats this matter with the seriousness it warrants. We see a special purpose and very special reasons for maintaining the proper and acceptable links with our near neighbour New Zealand. I think that even Mr Muldoon would have to admit that things have changed slightly internationally since 1920. This is not a matter that has been raised for the first time by the Government in the last few months. It has gone across the political spectrum. It was first raised by a Labor government when my very dear friend Mr Clyde Cameron was the Minister for Labor and Immigration. The matter has been pursued ever since.

SPEECH.PARA: We in the Opposition in no way want to see fractured the long-standing relationship that has existed between Australia and New Zealand. But the statement provokes from us the necessity of making a decision. It is not something upon which the Opposition can sit on the fence in the hope of winning some political favour. It has always been my view that in these matters it is best, if possible, for the country to speak with one voice so that people outside Australia are able to read that both the major political parties which may form the government of this country are near to the same view on these questions-in this case, specifically the relationship between Australia and New Zealand.

I do not agree with the statements that have been made by the New Zealand Prime Minister about the step that has been taken as detailed in the announcement of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Thousands and thousands of Australians and New Zealanders visit each other's country every year. This is something that we want to encourage. It is because of those visits that we have such a close relationship. Many people in both countries want to see each other's country before they go anywhere else in the world. I think that we have been generous at a government level in the way in which the governments of the day of various political colours have allowed people, and encouraged people, to travel between our two countries. But problems have existed. It would be futile for any person in public life to think that the present system could have continued without the problems escalating.

It may not be true, but it appears to be true, that people who are carrying on some sort of criminal activity at the international level want to make their way to Australia. We have read just recently that there is a bumper opium crop in the Golden Triangle of South East Asia. The American and international groups which are working on trying to prevent this large escalation of production of opium will not know the impact of their work until they are able to get some idea of how much of it finds its way on to the streets, as they say in their document, of New York, London, Paris and Sydney. Australia is looked upon by international pedlars as a clearing house for drugs.

It is true, and I do not think anybody would argue, that some people have found it convenient to come into Australia via New Zealand because of the easy access they may have to that country. I think we should make it quite clear that in no way are we condemning or throwing a blanket across the whole of the New Zealand people. But New Zealanders have a different system of allowing people into New Zealand to that which exists here. Anybody who has been outside the country knows that there is some difficulty getting back in. Even the shadow Minister last Sunday had to queue up for over an hour to have his documents inspected before he could get back into Australia. But that is not the case with New Zealand because of its easy visa system with so many countries. From information which has been given to me from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs I understand that these countries include Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Japan, Luxemburg, Malta, Monaco, Norway, Switzerland, Sweden, Tahiti, the United Kingdom-as one would expect-the United States of America, West Germany, Iceland and Ireland. Citizens of those countries can go to New Zealand without a visa. They cannot do this if they wish to come to Australia. This means that if they arrive in New Zealand they have not been screened by the New Zealand authorities in New Zealand or by the New Zealand authorities or people acting for them in the country where application for a visa has been made. So it is a much simpler process for a person to go to New Zealand in the first instance than it is for him to obtain for a visa to come to Australia.

Discussions on this matter have been conducted over the last seven years. If we could have worked out some system whereby both countries had the same level of scrutiny of people who wished to visit our respective countries the announcement made by the Minister may not have been warranted. The whole thing could have been avoided. The net could have been set up at an earlier stage and people would have been discouraged from trying to enter New Zealand in the same way as they are discouraged from entering Australia because of the system which applies in this country. No system, of course, is perfect. The people we are dealing with are very clever people. They falsify documents. They are used to breaking through the barriers set up by the various bureaucracies around the world. They are dealing in vast amounts of money. Bribery and corruption exist wherever they go. At least we ought to make it as tough as possible for them to enter this country.

The first editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald following the Minister's announcement stated that we were using a sledgehammer to crack a nut in Australia. If we are saying to the ordinary, decent New Zealand citizen 'We want you to have a passport because we are trying to stop some other people entering Australia' it may appear that way. I am sure that every thinking Australian will support the move which, in some way, will prevent people from bringing drugs into this country. I believe it is a step that has been taken by many other countries. It is a great pity, perhaps, that the system which applies in Australia was not adopted by the New Zealand Government itself. As I said earlier, this matter has been negotiated for years. The Opposition tonight cannot embrace the idea as though it were its own exclusively. We in the Opposition cannot say that the idea is going to work and keep out all the people that we hope it will keep out. We do say that it is certainly worth a try. I do not think that it will impose an enormous burden because the figures which have been provided show that a good proportion of the people travelling to Australia from New Zealand already hold a passport.

I raise the question-I am sure many other people raise it also-why people coming from New Zealand require a passport; surely there must be a simpler way of identifying a person who travels between Australia and New Zealand. If we are dealing with the sorts of people that I talked of earlier we are dealing with very skilful people. They would easily falsify a simple social security document, if that is what the people who asked the question had in mind. It may be that it is a more difficult task for such people to falsify a passport. We have a responsibility to our own people in Australia. Perhaps some people in New Zealand will be upset by the announcement. Time will show. If the new system is a failure we can alter it, go back to the old system and hope that we can catch the people we are endeavouring to catch. If it proves successful-figures will be available to show whether it is successful-it will show that the step taken by Australia was correct. I am sure that the evidence available to New Zealand is making that country think again about the procedures which it has adopted. New Zealand must be finding that many people are illegally entering that country as well.

Many people in this country say that New Zealanders are already given special treatment and that this system is not going to change the special treatment that they are given. On behalf of members of the Opposition I say categorically that we support the special relationship that exists between Australia and New Zealand. We do not support, nor would we give support to, adopting a visa system whereby people would have to apply for a visa to travel backwards and forwards between the two countries. Let me assure the House that people working amongst the ethnic communities in this country and many of the very influential spokespeople in the ethnic communities who come from other parts of the world think people coming from New Zealand should be treated in the same way as they are treated. They believe New Zealanders should have to apply for a visa to come here. If one asked the Minister or any other person in Australia who has access to the figures-if they were truthful; I am sure they would be-they would indicate that they did not know how many people from New Zealand settle in Australia. They could tell us the number of travellers who came from New Zealand, but they could not tell us the number of people who say that they are only coming to Australia for one month, two months or three months but who never go home.

We have to understand that Australia and New Zealand have a common labour market. If jobs are available in Australia but not in New Zealand Australia will attract a number of people to work in this country. The reverse situation would apply. If jobs were available in certain categories in New Zealand and Australians were out of work people would be heading to New Zealand. That happens. It is not one way traffic. More New Zealanders are coming to live in Australia. Substantial numbers of Australians find it convenient to live in New Zealand. As I said earlier, many people in Australia believe we should not have a special relationship with New Zealand and that we should impose on that country the same hurdles-if I can use that term-that are placed before the people of Greek, Italian, Yugoslav or Lebanese communities. I do not support that view. I hope that no one in this Parliament supports that view. Australia has a history of co-operation and special interest with New Zealand. That is what should happen.

This new measure will assist in catching common criminals who come to Australia from New Zealand. It will help to prevent Australian criminals from escaping easily to New Zealand and vice versa. It will stop the common criminal from New Zealand making his way into Australia. As the Minister said in his speech, some of these common criminals have been deported on multiple occasions. They merely change their name when they buy their ticket and fill out their incoming card. We have to spend Australian taxpayers' money sending them back to New Zealand. I would go so far as to say that the new system that has been announced by the Government-it was initiated by Clyde Cameron when the Labor Party was in office-is worth a try. I do not think we should be wildly enthusiastic that it will solve all the problems that confront us. I think we will win the general support of the people if the Parliament speaks with one voice. New Zealanders themselves may then understand that it is not a measure on which we are widely split. I think the Parliament to a very large extent agrees that this measure should be adopted. I think New Zealanders ought to understand clearly that there is no proposal in this country to adopt the easy visa system which has been established in that country. We are not attempting to interfere and say that New Zealand should not have that system. That is New Zealand's business and its decision. I think there would be wholesale opposition in this country to the abolition of the visa system for any number of countries, particularly bearing in mind the number of countries from which New Zealand does not require a visa.

Evidence has been before us and questions have been raised in the past seven years. I have gone to the trouble since this matter was raised with me of having long discussions with Clyde Cameron. Perhaps he would have taken an even tougher stance in Parliament had he been here tonight because of evidence which was placed before him as the Minister for Labor and Immigration in 1975. Nonetheless I think this step will win the support of the Australian people. We ought to keep a very close watch on its impact. It ought to be monitored. Reports ought to be presented to the Parliament every 12 months so that the Government can answer any criticisms which may come either from within Australia or, more specifically, from the people in New Zealand. The New Zealand Prime Minister said that perhaps this will in some way permantly fracture the enormously good relationships between Australia and New Zealand. I hope that those words will not come true. I certainly-I am sure this applies to my party-do not wish to see that occur. We are looking forward to very good and fruitful relationships with New Zealand. We believe this step taken by the Government will in no way fracture that relationship.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1980-81 as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these two measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills now before the House are the normal supplementary Bills to provide appropriations to cover increased costs of various programs, mainly through wage increases, and to provide funds for new programs such as some that were introduced to fulfil election promises. In a sense these Bills are very ordinary and commonplace. However, in one sense I suppose they are different in that they are rather remarkable because of the fact that they are here. One of the quite amazing aspects of the Parliament so far this year has been the absence of legislation. This Government seems to be suffering from legislative constipation, an inability to bring legislation before the House, with the result that most of our time in the last several weeks has been taken up with the discussion of statements of various kinds, including the rather amazing discussion we had today. At last we have substantive legislation before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Although these Bills are commonplace and ordinary, they open up the possibility of substantial discussion of economic policy and therefore they are, indeed, important. The cost of the new appropriations contained in these two Bills is in the order of $520m, an increase of some 40 per cent on what was involved in these Bills last year. That cost is offset by savings in appropriations of some $148m. These so-called savings amount to adjustments of appropriations in Appropriation Bills (Nos 1 and 2) which were passed by Parliament in the Spring session last year. Those appropriations are now being cut back in the way spelt out in the statement of savings expected in annual appropriations which has been published by the Government.

I pause briefly to look at those so-called savings, those cut-backs in appropriations which were passed by the Parliament last year. Honourable members will notice that in the area of defence there is a saving of some $66m, $52m of which is on new equipment. There is a saving or cut-back in veterans' affairs of $12m. That means the whole of the appropriation for the Defence Service Homes Corporation is not to be spent this year. In the area of social security there is a cut-back of $5.6m, $2.9m of which is for aged and disabled persons' homes and $2.6m for aged persons' hostels. In each case it amounts to a reduction in the appropriation of some 10 per cent-a quite substantial reduction, given the inadequate nature of the original appropriations in the first place. Education is cut back by some $7.3m, most of which relates to a 20 per cent reduction in the appropriation for the school to work transition program. In housing and construction there is a reduction of $15m, of which $5m, representing a reduction of 10 per cent, is from the Homes Savings Grant Scheme. So, that inadequate appropriation is to be further cut back as well. One area which interests me considerably is that of Aboriginal affairs, where there is a cut-back of $800,000, of which $148,000 is for communication to Aurukun and Mornington Island. None of the allocation is to be spent this year.

These so-called savings in appropriations include cut-backs in areas which clearly are areas of undeniable need. The Opposition takes the view that it is appalling that these cut-backs have occurred. I note in particular that for aged persons' accommodation-which, as I have already mentioned has been cut back by some $2.9m-there was an appropriation for 1980-81 of only 36 per cent of the real level for 1975-76, the last year of the Labor Government. So, that appropriation was way below the real level of expenditure under Labor and now it is being further cut back by some 10 per cent. This is an area of quite obviously undeniable need. The fact that these cut-backs are being made-of course there are further cut-backs to come later this week with the announcement of the razor gang report-indicates the Government's anti-public sector bias and its lack of concern for programs to assist people in real need.

I pass on from these cut-backs in appropriations to look more generally at the state of the economy and the effectiveness or otherwise of the Government's economic policies. The Government is continually claiming that economic recovery is under way and that this is attributable to the Government's economic policies. Earlier tonight the Treasurer (Mr Howard) reiterated these claims. The Opposition does not deny that some degree of economic recovery has occurred and is occurring, but I make three points about that. Firstly, we say it is not as extensive as the Government claims; secondly, it is happening largely because of the failure of the Government to achieve particular policy objectives and because of factors beyond the control of the Australian Government; and, thirdly, the likelihood of recovery continuing will be determined largely by the extent to which the Government fails to achieve policy objectives. I now turn to a consideration of those three points. I refer firstly to the extent of the recovery. A month ago the Treasurer said:
We are now starting to see, quite unambiguously . . . the evidence of strong growth in the Australian economy.

Let us look at the supposed evidence for that growth. The evidence to which the Treasurer referred was, in the main, the movement in the total output of goods and services. Rates of growth have certainly increased but they are still not high by past measures. Budget forecasts were for gross domestic product to increase by 3 per cent or more and for non-farm gross product to increase by 3.5 per cent. In January this year the Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Stone, said that the growth in the gross domestic product would be less than 3 per cent because of the drought in Queensland and New South Wales affecting the farm sector. He said that growth in non-farm gross product would be about 3.5 per cent. At the end of March this year the Treasurer said that growth in non-farm gross product would increase by around 4 per cent-in other words, it would exceed the Budget forecast. More latterly he has again indicated that he expects it to be over 4 per cent. In fact, this claim is borne out by the latest national accounts. Growth in 1980 was about 4.3 per cent for non-farm gross product but the growth in gross domestic product was only 3.1 per cent because of a 15 per cent fall in farm product.

If the assumption of growth in excess of 4 per cent is true it is an improvement on the Budget forecast and an improvement on the growth rates over the last few years. However, those rates, of course, were abysmally low. For the first four full financial years of the Fraser Government the average rate of growth in gross domestic product was only 2.4 per cent compared with the rate of 6 per cent to 7 per cent which the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) claimed was attainable in his 1975 policy speech. We have had anything but growth rates of 6 per cent to 7 per cent. Current estimates of growth of approxi- mately 4 per cent or more can be seen as strong or satisfactory only in the light of the very diminished expectations flowing from the experience of the last few years. The rates of growth are better than those of the last few years, but, of course, they were abysmal.

It is most important to note also that by far the best year for the Fraser Government was the 1976 calendar year in which the course of the economy was determined mainly by the policy adopted by the Labor Government. In that year non-farm gross product increased by 6.6 per cent. The growth rate since has been nothing like that. Once the Fraser Government's policies got into full swing growth rates were substantially reduced. As I have said, in the first four years they averaged a mere 2.4 per cent.

It is also said by the Government that our growth this year is better than that in most of the other developed countries. That of course is true but we have been affected much less by the 150 per cent rise in world oil prices in the 18 months to the middle of 1980 than have most other countries. This is something that the Government continually skips over but it is absolutely fundamental to understanding why the experience of Australia in respect of growth in 1980 has been different from that of most of the other developed countries. There was in the 18 months to the middle of 1980 an enormous increase of 150 per cent in oil prices. This was known as the second oil shock after the first shock of October 1973 in which oil prices quadrupled overnight.

Although the rest of the world has been very adversely affected by the increase in oil prices we have been protected from the adverse impact on our balance of payments of those higher oil prices because we produce 70 per cent of our oil needs. Most other developed countries have suffered severe balance of payments dislocation because of this factor. In other words, the greatly increased cost of oil has led to a large increase in their import bills which has caused the dislocation of their balance of payments and therefore led them to adopt policies which contract other imports in an attempt to achieve balance of payments equilibrium. To reduce imports they have adopted tough, contractionary fiscal and monetary policies which are dually designed to reduce the demand for imports and also to prevent inflation getting out of control as the higher oil prices feed into their economies. The international recession which is very obvious at present has been induced principally by the direct and indirect effects of the second oil shock; that is, the direct effects on the balance of payments and inflation and the indirect effects through the tough fiscal and monetary policies adopted to overcome the direct effects. The recession has been exacerbated in some countries by the resort to Friedmanite monetarist policies in countries such as Britain in particular.

Although our exports have been adversely affected by a consequent diminution in world demand for them and by drought we have, nevertheless, been largely protected from the international recession, not only because of our substantial self-sufficiency in oil but also because the dramatic world oil price rise has made our energy resources much more attractive as nations seek to move rapidly away from petroleum as an energy source. This is a tremendously important point. Not only have we been protected by meeting 70 per cent of our oil needs from our own resources but also the increased oil prices have made Australian energy far more attractive than it was previously. Hence, there has been a dramatic increase in investment in resources and resource related industries over the last year. We have been a double beneficiary. On the one hand we have been largely protected and on the other we have benefited because of the much greater attractiveness of resource development in this country.

It is this large resource investment surge which is fuelling growth in Australia at the same time as the cause of that surge, the second world oil shock, is causing acute economic difficulties leading to an actual decline in output in several developed countries. The extent of our insulation from the world oil price hike has been diminished by the unnecessary importation of its inflationary consequences through the adoption of import parity pricing for Australian produced oil. That policy has meant a dramatic rise in petroleum prices and taxes and is the major reason why our inflation rate still hovers around the 10 per cent mark. Without import parity we would have been much more protected from the inflationary recession besetting the rest of the world.

A further point regarding the Government's claim that our growth rate is good compared with other countries in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development is that in the first four years of the Fraser Government our rate of growth was abysmally below that of comparable countries. Real gross domestic product per head in Australia grew by 1.2 per cent per annum in those four years compared with 4.1 per cent for our industrialised trading partners. Until last year in the period of the Fraser Government in this country our growth rates had been way behind those being achieved by the rest of the developed world. Thus, in this context, bearing in mind our great advantages over most other countries beset by rising world oil prices, we hardly have cause for self-congratulation at present.

Another aspect to look at in regard to the supposed recovery is employment. The Government continually points to rising employment as a sign of economic recovery. Certainly on the available figures there has been notable employment growth over the last two years. But it is important to note also that that growth has been slowing down. Since the Government ordered the Commonwealth Statistician not to publish figures for wage and salary earners in civilian employment each month the only published guide to employment is the monthly labour force figures. These show that the maximum annual growth for employed persons in Australia occurred in July 1980. In the 12-month period to July 1980 employment growth reached its maximum of some 212,000. Since then, however, there has been a clear downward trend with a lower figure for almost every successive month. The latest figure for February 1981 shows an annual rate of growth of only 146,000. That is still a substantial figure but it is far less than the rate of growth in July last year. It is important to note that that trend is still on a downward path.

If we look at the figures for full time employment they show an even greater decline in the rate of employment growth. In the 12 months to May 1980 they rose by 182,000 but there were successive monthly declines in the rate of growth thereafter so that in the 12 months to February 1981 they rose by only 105,000 or two per cent. Clearly, the employment growth rate has been declining, especially with regard to full time employment. Also, the number of registered unemployed in February 1981 was 19,500 higher than in February 1980-in total 482,000-that is, approaching half a million unemployed. Such developments on the employment front put all this Government's talk of strong economic growth in some perspective. The fact is that the rate of employment growth has substantially declined in the last six months. What has occurred has not prevented higher unemployment. To claim in these circumstances that strong economic recovery is occurring is clearly absurd. How can we have strong economic recovery occurring if we have diminishing rates of employment growth and rising unemployment? To claim that Australia is out of the recession, as the Treasurer (Mr Howard) said a month or so ago, when we have almost half a million people unemployed and the number of unemployed increasing, is clearly crass stupidity.

I turn to the second point regarding the idea that recovery has occurred largely because of events beyond government's control and because of the failure of the Government to achieve certain policy objectives. Firstly, I turn to the consideration of events beyond government control. That is, of course, principally referring to the massive rise in world oil prices to which I have already referred. This factor brought about the consequent investment surge that has occurred in resource projects and resource related industries. There is simply no denying that private investment has increased considerably, if not spectacularly, over the last 12 to 18 months. The latest figures show that new fixed capital expenditure by private enterprise for the September quarter 1980 was 37 per cent above the level for the September quarter of the previous year. Expected investment in the December quarter 1980 was 50 per cent above the actual investment in the December quarter 1979 and 25 per cent above the actual investment in the September quarter 1980. Those figures certainly demonstrate considerable investment growth.

The major areas of investment growth are in the mining industry, the processing of basic metals, and in finance. The latter area is, of course, closely associated with the investment surge in the resource areas. The process of capital raising is becoming infinitely more important given the enormous amounts of capital needed for these resource projects with the inevitable consequence that the finance industry has also become a major growth area. Altogether, the large rise in business investment will add substantially to non-farm gross product this year. Professor Nevile estimated that the Budget forecast of a 10 per cent real growth in investment would increase non-farm gross product directly and indirectly by a little over 1 per cent. If, however, the growth of investment is possibly as much as 20 per cent-this could be the case-that could add something like 2 per cent to non-farm gross product.

But capital investment is not the only source of growth at present. To the extent that that occurs, it is not attributable to Government policy but rather to the fortuitous large increase in oil prices and the availability of alternative energy resources in Australia. There are other sources of growth. Some other sources are purely domestic in origin. The irrefutable fact in relation to each of these domestic sources of increased growth is that they result from the failure of the Government to achieve its policy objectives rather than the successful implementation of those policies. For instance, the increase in retail sales is pointed to as some evidence of an increase in consumer expenditure.

There certainly has been some increase in real terms during the last year. In the three months to February 1981, in comparison with the same three months in the previous year, there was a rise of 15 per cent which, after allowing for a 10 per cent rise in the goods component of the consumer price index and a population rise of a little over 1 per cent, still shows some notable real growth. Rather than proving that Government policy is working, this growth in consumer expenditure must surely be attributed to the fact that real wages have increased in the last year for the first time in five years. I think it is important to note that in the first four years of the Fraser Government there was, in fact, a reduction in the level of real wages in this country. We can hardly expect there to be a growth in consumer expenditure at a time when the real incomes of most consumers-that is, wage and salary earners-were in fact being reduced.

The Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research has calculated that in the whole history of Australia as a federation-back to 1900-there have been only four five-year periods in which there have been reductions in real wages. Those four periods are during the First World War, during the Second World War, during the Great Depression of the 1930s and during the five years up to 1979-in other words, in the first four years of the Fraser Government's period of office. The reduction in real wages which has occurred under this Government is not a normal phenomenon; it has been a quite marked and distinctly different thing from what has happened over most of the five-year periods in the course of our history as a nation. It has been a dramatically important development and one which has most certainly restricted the possibility of an expansion of consumer expenditure. Last year there was, in fact, an increase in real wages. That increase in real wages gave wage earners a capacity to spend that they did not have before. That therefore led to some increase in retail sales and consumer expenditures generally.

But it must be recognised that that occurred completely againt Government policy. It was not Government policy for there to be an increase in real wages. The Government is still talking of the need to reduce the level of real wages. It is certainly not for allowing them to increase. The increase in consumer expenditures resulted from an increase in real wages. The Government likes to take credit for the increase in consumer expenditure but abhors the reason for it-the increase in the real capacity of wage earners to buy goods and services. Similarly, if we look at the public sector we can see a complete contradiction between the Government's proclaimed policy of reducing the public sector and what happened in this financial year. The Budget involved a real 3 per cent increase in public expenditure. Of course, it did that because 1980-81 was an election year. It was fortuitous electorally to use the Budget to increase Government expenditures in various areas.

Professor Nevile at the University of New South Wales, who is a foremost fiscal analyst in this country, has calculated that that 3 per cent growth in public expenditure will add 1.5 per cent to non-farm gross product in this financial year. Public expenditure growth, which is the source of the public sector stimulus, is providing a considerable degree of economic growth this year and is a major cause of the increase in the rates of growth. A 1.5 per cent increase in our growth rate is not to be sneezed at. Yet this is coming from an increase in public sector expenditures which the Government says basically that it is against. The Government does not explain how it came to give the 3 per cent increase last year. The Government is obviously in a contradictory situation. Once again the Government's failure to adhere to its policy of reducing the public sector has been a major factor in increasing the level of demand and so achieving the higher rate of economic growth. Yet the Government claims that this higher growth is attributable to the success of its economic policies. This is obviously absurd.

In regard to the building industry, there was some pick-up of activity in 1980, the details of which I will not give because of time pressures. Such expansion again is clearly attributable more to the Government's failure to adhere to its money supply targets in 1980, thus enabling easier access to credit than would otherwise have been the case, than it is to any aspect of Government policy. In 1979-80 the Government's money supply target was 10 per cent. The actual growth of money supply as measured by M3 was 13 per cent but these figures obscure the considerable volatility in the rates of growth of the money supply which have generally been allowed to run well ahead of the target rate over most of the year, only approaching the target rate near the end of the financial year. This has been very evident in the current financial year with the money supply allowed to run way ahead of target prior to the election. Indeed, the growth rate of M1 in the three months to November 1980 was an extraordinary 26 per cent. For 1980, M1 rose by 17 per cent and M3 rose by 13 per cent, both well above the targeted levels.

It is not to be unexpected, therefore, that an industry such as the building industry, which is basically dependent upon the availability of credit, would respond favourably to this easier credit environment even though it was accompanied by interest rate rises in April and July 1980. Activity in many other industries would be stimulated by the building industry growth and by the greater availability of credit. Thus yet again, by failing to adhere to or achieve the announced policy, this time in relation to the controlling of the money supply, the Government has stimulated investment in the buiding industry and in the economy generally. It then claims that this is evidence of the success of its policies.

It can be clearly seen from this analysis that such recovery as has occurred has been predominantly due to specific failures by the Government to achieve its declared objectives-that is, to contain wage growth, to reduce the size of the public sector, to restrict the rate of growth of the money supply-and to the world oil price rise which is clearly not attributable to government policy. It follows then that rather than bearing out the Government's claims of the success of its policies the fact that there is some economic recovery demonstrates quite the opposite-that is, that when a more stimulatory policy is implemented than has been applied previously the economy responds to that stimulus. That is what the Opposition has been maintaining all along. Accordingly what has happened in regard to the increased growth rate bears out the validity of the economic policies advocated by the Opposition rather than demonstrate the success of the Government's economic strategy.

The third point I wish to raise relates to the likelihood of this modest recovery being maintained in the future. This depends, as I say, on whether the Government continues to fail to achieve particular policy targets. Since past failure to achieve policy targets in areas of money supply growth, wages and the public sector have clearly stimulated the economy, it follows that recovery continuance depends on whether the Government continues to fail in those areas. Unfortunately it seems that the Government is likely to achieve its objectives in these areas this year, especially in regard to the money supply in the public sector; so economic recovery will accordingly be held back.

In regard to the money supply, increases in the interest rates after the election and a widening gap in the balance of payments current account mean that the money supply rate of growth is now declining and has reached the upper levels of the target rate of growth of between 9 per cent and 11 per cent. It is slightly above that level because of the slight increase in the March quarter, but it is still near the target rate of 11 per cent. Furthermore, this contraction in the annual rate of growth of money supply has involved a sharp continuation in money supply growth over the last few years. In the three months to February 1981, M1, in fact, declined by one per cent and M3 grew by only 9 per cent. This was before the seasonal run-down in the money supply which occurs from April to June when company and provisional tax payments become due, and there is a heavy drawing down of liquid funds from the banks. In these circumstances, it is difficult to believe we are not entering a period of acute tightening of credit, with the consequent adverse effects on growth in the building industry and in the economy as a whole.

We are later this week to have revealed to us what the Government has decided to do to cut back on public sector spending which will mean that there will not be stimulus coming from this area either. In those circumstances I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'whilst not opposing the provisions of the Bill, the House-
(a) deplores the failure of the Government to fully spend appropriations in important areas of Government expenditure;
(b) rejects the Government's claims that the improvements in economic growth that have occurred recently have been due to the effects of Government policies;

(c) recognises that such modest recovery as has occurred is due to the failure of the Government to achieve particular policy objectives and to factors beyond the control of the Australian Government;
(d) notes with alarm the gathering signs of an acute credit squeeze as exemplified by record and rising interest rates and shortages of home mortgage finance;

(e) expresses its concern that severely restrictive monetary policies and a threatened tightening of fiscal policy will produce a renewed downturn in the rate of economic growth, and a further rise in unemployment, and
(f) accordingly expresses its complete lack of confidence in Government economic policies'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dean Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we consider Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) this evening I believe it is an appropriate time for any government and any member on the Government side to consider what are or ought to be policy objectives and, in that context, to consider what ought to be appropriated in order to support those objectives. In passing I would simply reject the amendment moved by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis). In my speech this evening, rather than discuss in broad terms the economy as such, I thought, given this is an appropriate time to consider policies, I would consider some areas that may be appropriate for policy consideration. I do so on a couple of bases. The first is that we have to accept that our society is changing, even if some of the changes that we see about us are not very palatable at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: In any time of change the government of the day must be responsive to that change as well as responsible in government. It must be sensitive as well as sensible. It must be a government that is aware of the needs of all Australians and willing to take the initiatives which society will, it is hoped, quite happily follow. It must be prepared to look at policy problems and at issues broadly and flexibly so that the appropriate response in these changing times can be articulated. As I said, rather than discuss the economy in broad terms I thought I would narrow the discussion to four areas: Firstly, the question of industrial relations; secondly, the future in energy and energy research; thirdly, the need to develop new industries in this nation; and, fourthly, the future of immigration and immigration policy in Australia. These four issues are all of great importance in themselves. In my view they are issues that will consume a good deal of time, discussion and debate as the 1980s roll on.

In talking about industrial relations, it is certainly not my purpose to indulge in a spate of union bashing, much as I for one might have a reason to be rather angry about the strike of the airline hostesses seeing that the strike prevented me from getting home to my electorate last weekend. That is not my purpose. Rather, I am concerned about the fact that as the 1980s go on the tendency for industrial disputation to take place in sensitive or key areas will have a very deleterious effect on the development of this nation. Going back to the bases that I enunciated at the beginning of my speech, we have to be able to look at the issue widely and flexibly so that we can articulate and develop appropriate responses. It is not just a question of considering such things as the current issue of the 35-hour week. The overall and wide-ranging adoption of a 35-hour week would be immediately damaging but, in the longer term, we have to be prepared to consider changes in working hours along with a whole range of other possible policy options.

For example, one of the things that we ought to be prepared to do is to make permanent part time work much more of an option in future working patterns. We must be prepared to consider ways in which we can avoid unnecessary disputation in key areas. I am not necessarily wedded to the idea that we should have something like the United States Taft-Hartley provisions in relation to national emergency strikes. Nevertheless, we ought to be prepared to consider ways in which we can avoid disputation, particularly in these sorts of key areas. We ought to be prepared to consider much more fully than so far has been done the idea of working as between employer and employee on an industry award basis, the so-called industry unions, or perhaps the establishment of industry agreements which do operate in some areas. The discussion ought to be re-opened about the States themselves vesting various of their own powers in relation to industrial matters to the Commonwealth as one way of achieving a more nation-wide response to the difficulties that we face.

Naturally enough a good number of advantages could flow from moving to accepting part time work on a permanent basis. Permanent part time work is eminently suitable for, for example, married women. It is worth bearing in mind that it is an accepted fact that there still are increasing numbers of married women who are seeking employment of some sort or another. It is interesting to note that in 1979 some 72,000 married women were looking for work, compared with 40,000 in 1974. It is an increasing phenomenon. The provision of what we might call permanent part time work for them is obviously an attraction to them. Single parents, pensioners and people who do not want to go into a higher tax bracket would find permanent part time work attractive, that is, work that is not just provided on a casual basis but rather has a degree of permanency about it that we would associate with normal full time work.

I return to the broad theme of industrial relations that we are discussing. I appeal for the government of the day to consider the most flexible of approaches because this is a changing society and we have to be prepared to meet changes flexibly and appropriately. One of the things that is of concern regarding energy, quite apart from the generally argued proposition that insufficient time or effort is being put into energy research in Australia, is that a good deal of energy research funding follows what we might call an almost predictable pattern. In other words, we tend to continue to fund the sorts of projects and research that have been funded in the past. Sometimes it seems to me that there is a failure to be more imaginative in our funding of research programs.

In this respect I mention a couple of research programs that are taking place in my electorate through the James Cook University of north Queensland. They are not currently being funded, yet they are projects which, I think, could demonstrate a need to be funded. Yet perhaps because of the fettered approach I mentioned before, the fetters of precedence, these projects so far have not been funded. The first I mention is a research program into using the humble peanut. It is a product for which Kingaroy is fairly famous. For those who may not know, it is a product that is also grown fairly extensively in north Queensland, particularly on the Atherton Tablelands. Peanut oil has properties which can make it very useful in diesel motors. I am not technically minded and I do not understand the technicalities of it, but apparently one of the advantageous properties of peanut oil is that it is a dry oil. It is a better quality oil than many other oils that are being experimented as alternatives to dieselene. The James Cook University of north Queensland has had a demonstration project going for nigh on two years in order to prove the properties of peanut oil in diesel motors, to compare them with conventionally fuelled motors, and to prove that peanut oil can be a useful and viable alternative, particularly for on-farm use.

A little while ago the University put in a request to the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council for funding of its research project, and failed. It is being submitted again. I use this as an example of the way in which one fears that energy research funding is simply going along the accepted lines of funding the sorts of things that have been funded before. Yet when we see the possibilities of this research and the possibilities of quite viable on-farm use in a regional part of the nation, we wonder why it cannot be seen to be worthy of funding. It is something that goes back to what I said in the beginning-flexibility of approach, imagination to meet changing needs and circumstances. In considering its appropriations in the future the government of the day ought to be concerned about these matters.

Another piece of research, part of which is carried on in the north Queensland region, is research into the use of tallow as a fuel source. Again I mention that I am not technically minded and in this speech I do not propose to attempt to go in to the way in which that solid matter, tallow, can be used to fuel diesel motors. It can be done apparently by using some dieselene to start a motor and heat it and then switching over to tallow, which has been made liquid by the heat that the machine is generating. However, when one considers the number of export meatworks that exist around the nation, it is an area of research that appears to be worthy of funding. Yet the fetters of precedent appear to ensure that it misses out. As we consider the energy future of this nation, we have to be prepared to consider not just the traditional coal-to-oil or shale-to-oil processes but also to be imaginative and to research other interesting and perhaps promising areas and to ensure that in future years support is given where it is needed.

The development of new industries is an area, of course, that one could go into at great length and produce all sorts of examples about. At this time of the night, in this debate, I do not have the time to do that. But I do touch briefly upon the part that tourism can play in Australia. It might sound as though I am hitting a tired old theme but, when one considers that Australia does not get a very large part of the international tourist market, when one considers that the nation has a tremendous amount to offer in safety, free from disease and when one considers that there are vast parts of this land to be opened up to tourism, then it certainly can be seen that tourism is one of those newer developing industries which this nation can take hold of to its advantage as the 1980s proceed.

Again I can use an example from my electorate of the way in which so very few international visitors, even very few Australians, see a quite remarkable part of the world. Yet there it is to be offered and promoted. The Government has, of course, introduced some very good initiatives to promote tourism internationally for Australia. I think of the Budget allocations in recent years for the Australian Tourist Commission. I think of the introduction of depreciation on tourist acommodation buildings. But more can be done. At least these initiatives ought to be pursued, and certainly I would see the Australian Tourist Commission, as the 1980s evolve, having a far greater role in the promotion of tourism than it presently has. It is an industry that is labour intensive and will create jobs for this nation. It can grow with the nation in the 1980s. It certainly is an industry worthy of very considered and considerable support as required.

Finally, I refer to immigration. I believe that immigration will perhaps be the biggest single debate area of the latter 1980s. As we develop our natural resources and as we take advantage of the so-called resources boom, so we will find the need to have a much higher immigration intake than at present for two reasons. Firstly, we may simply need greater numbers of skilled workers in various areas; secondly, we will want to match resource development with our domestic population base. Hence as a nation we will have to consider most seriously taking in far greater numbers of immigrants than we have in recent years. That brings with it one other very large area for consideration. When we think about an increased intake of migrants to this nation we will certainly have to consider our relationships with South East Asian nations and the intake of migrants from that part of the globe.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the House to the speech made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) two days before the last Federal election in October 1980 in which he pledged to give back increases in the crude oil levy from 1 January 1981 as rebates on family allowances. This pledge was subsequently widely publicised in the media prior to the election. I draw the attention of the House also to the address given by the Governor-General in which he said that the Government would be looking closely at its family policies with the objective of further enhancing the position of Australian families. As yet these pledges and commitments are mere rhetoric.

SPEECH.PARA: The increase in the oil levy for the first six months of this year, according to the Treasurer (Mr Howard), will be $170m. According to figures provided by the Parliamentary Library and outlined in the other House by Senator Harradine on 26 March this amount of $170m would mean monthly increases in family allowances as follows: For the first child an increase of $5.80, for the second child an increase of $8.30, for the third child an increase of $10, for the fourth child an increase of $10 and for the fifth and subsequent children an increase of $11.65. This is what could be done for Australian families which would provide across-the-board average increases in the order of 22 per cent.

Honourable members may recall that the family allowance system was established in 1976 when child endowment payments and rebates for children were abolished. The new scheme was estimated to cost $1,020m per annum, or $785m more than the annual cost of child endowment. However, the savings to the Government through the abolition of the rebate scheme was almost equal to this cost. There was, therefore, in effect little net cost to the Budget in 1976-77. The family allowance has remained the same since 1976. It has not been indexed to the cost of living increases. In June 1976 the family allowance for the first child as a percentage of the average weekly wage was 1.95 per cent. Today it represents only 1.21 per cent of the average weekly wage. Over this same period living costs have risen at an enormous rate-according to the CPI, in excess of 60 per cent. Consequently the family allowance has been eroded in excess of 60 per cent during that period.

In 1941 the Child Endowment Act provided for the payment of an endowment, as it was then called, at a flat rate of 5s a week. This 5s represented the amount calculated to be the cost of keeping a child for a week. The present amounts of $15.20 a month for one child, $36.90 for two children, $62.90 for three children and $88.90 for four children would do little to meet the cost of keeping a child in today's society. It is evident that all families have been seriously financially disadvantaged by the failure of the Government either to increase or to index family allowance payments. Not only has the allowance remained the same since June 1976 but also the Government is now paying less in family allowances. If the Government had retained a system of child rebates and endowment and had indexed the rebate in a manner similar to the dependent spouse rebate, the cost of this scheme would have exceeded that of the family allowance scheme after its first year of operation. It is estimated that the cost of this scheme in 1980-81 would have exceeded the cost of the family allowance by $458m. Does the Government have a firm commitment to the family allowance scheme or is it trying to phase it out, albeit quietly?

To be meaningful, any system of family allowance should be increased regularly to compensate for inflation. As I have already outlined, the present level of the allowance is little more than a token gesture of family support. The debate on the future of the family allowance allows us to explore the need to encourage the development of the family unit as a basic structure of our society. At present the economic difficulties faced by young couples today-I mention the costs of buying a house and meeting heavy loan repayments in particular-are forcing them to hold off having a family until they have reached an adequate level of security. Even then the pressure is on them to restrict themselves to having a small number of children. I do not suggest that at the present time the system of the family allowance is an effective means of encouraging and supporting the family.

One lady aged 76 from Hobart-I will not mention her name-went to New Zealand by the direct link from Hobart to Christchurch. She tried to get back prior to Easter. Because of the strike she could not get back. She finally had to fly from Christchurch to Sydney and from Sydney to Melbourne. She then had to wait and try to get back to Hobart. The result of a selfish act by air hostesses was pandemonium. They have a body representing them. Surely to goodness they must know what they are doing to the economy and what they are doing to the emotions of the Australian people. Surely they know what problems they are causing to the people of Australia. They are a privileged lot. I have called them 'pampered darlings'. I repeat that statement. They are pampered darlings.
