TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the House very briefly as the honourable member for Balaclava on a matter which I wanted to raise earlier in the day; that is, the death of a former member for Balaclava, Sir Percy Joske. I just want to record what I believe both sides of the House would wish to have recorded. I wish to pay a short tribute to Sir Percy. He had a very distinguished career at the Bar, in this House and as a judge. Above all he will be remembered as the pioneer of the Matrimonial Causes Act which was the first uniform divorce law in Australia and was the foundation for the law introduced by the Whitlam Government, passed by this House in 1975 and which will soon be updated further. It was a pioneering piece of legislation, undoubtedly the most effective piece of legislation initiated by a private member.

SPEECH.PARA: I make these observations not to intrude upon the time of private members but for the sake of the family of Sir Percy which I think should have recorded some of the esteem of the House. I would like to refer to the foreword by Sir Garfield Barwick to the fifth edition of the book Matrimonial Causes and Marriage Law and Practice Australia and New Zealand. Sir Garfield Barwick, as Attorney-General, said in January 1961:

When in 1951, Mr P. E. Joske, Q.C., became a member of the House of Representatives for the Victorian constituency of Balaclava one of his self-imposed tasks was to plead the case, in Parliament and in the community, of a uniform Australia-wide law of divorce.
Sir Garfield went on to say:

Mr Joske's first step was to carry this jurisdictional reform a stage further. He did it in the Matrimonial Causes Act 1955, which he himself introduced as a private Member's Bill. Two years later, with the Government's approval, he introduced, again as a private member, a comprehensive measure that dealt with the grounds of divorce as well as with questions of jurisdiction. This Bill was vigorously debated in the House of Representatives and outside, but was eventually replaced by a Government measure, which became law as the Matrimonial Causes Act 1959. It is fair to say that the Act could scarcely have been acceptable to the Parliament if it had not been for the earlier strenuous efforts of the member for Balaclava. The changes introduced by the Commonwealth Act were great in both detail and in principle. Apart from changes in the grounds of divorce, which are not now the same, in any State, as hitherto they have been, there are important procedural changes, involving new professional habits in every State, laid down by the Act and carried out in the Rules.

Because of the indulgence of the Opposition I will not proceed further with the tributes that were then paid except to say that in the parliamentary debates of 14 May 1959 Sir Garfield Barwick, in introducing what was then a Government measure, paid great tribute again to Sir Percy as the member for Balaclava for this private member's measure. I know Sir Percy is still held in high regard in my electorate of Balaclava. In fact last night I addressed a joint branch meeting of the Liberal Party. Condolence motions were moved and very complimentary things were said in memory of Sir Percy. He is remembered also by practitioners in the family law area because his book on Australian family law is still the principal authority. Also, I understand that the Clerks of this House and elsewhere are still referring people to his excellent work on the law of public meetings. He is a person whose works ought to be remembered by this House and I thank the House for the opportunity to record my comments on them.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The criticism of the winning scheme by Mr Norman Day, the architecture critic for the Melbourne Age, among others, has largely revolved around their preference for schemes by other finalists. The winning design by Frank Martin has not been challenged on functional or cost grounds.

(2) The site for the building has as yet not been changed. The Government is considering whether the National Archives building should be located on a site in the Parliamentary Zone instead of that originally chosen in Constitution Avenue.

(7) Briefly the Government's attitude to Archives is made clear in two areas of general activity. The second is the programmed development of new sophisticated and purpose-built repositories in all States and the ACT. The building programme will culminate in Canberra with the construction of a National Archives building. This National building will be supported by a large supplementary repository in the suburb of Mitchell which will become fully operational during April 1981.

(8) The issue of the resources necessary for effective operations in each of the areas mentioned in the question is now under review and every effort will be made within existing economic guidelines to make appropriate provisions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Advisory Council for the Handicapped

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: What recommendations made since December 1977 by the National Advisory Council for the Handicapped (a) have been accepted, (b) have been rejected, or (c) are still under consideration by the Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The National Advisory Council for the Handicapped has made 49 recommendations since December 1977. These are set out in its second and third reports tabled in May 1978 and May 1980 respectively.

These recommendations are directed not only to the Government, but also canvass the responsibilities of many authorities and bodies and, in some cases, the whole community. Therefore, they do not lend themselves to the straightforward categorisation sought by the honourable member's question.

The Council's views have been and will continue to be taken into account by the Government in its consideration of matters affecting people with disabilities. The following initiatives taken by the Government reflect specific recommendations of the National Advisory Council for the Handicapped:
the planning, themes and organisation of the International Year of Disabled Persons (Recs 8 (1978) and 1, 17-19 (1980))
the decision by the Australian Bureau of Statistics to conduct the first major sample survey of disabled people, during 1981 (Rec 35 (1980))

the Government's policy commitment to a National Employment Strategy for disabled persons and, in particular, the actions being undertaken by the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs involving expenditure of some $2.3 million (Recs 26-28 (1980))
the introduction, in the last Budget, of a major aids and appliances scheme for disabled people (Council has consistently stressed the need for such a scheme)
the new three-year funding program under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act and the associated measures to upgrade the program. (Rec 15 (1980))
library services for handicapped people are being extended and improved as a response to sustained interest and involvement by Council (1978)
the Report of the Committee of Inquiry into Education and Training gave particular attention to the needs of disabled students (Rec 1 (1978))

the Schools Commission arranged for a major survey of special education, in Australia which estimated, amongst other things, the numbers of institutionalised children for whom adequate educational and developmental programs were needed (Rec 5 (1978))
the allocation of an additional $2 million to develop educational programs for severely handicapped children (Rec 5 (1978 and 1980))

the production of two booklets to alert parents and others to signs of disability in children and encourage them to take appropriate action. Additional child assessment centres are receiving grants to make their services more visible and accessible (Recs 11-12 (1980))

my colleagues, the Ministers for Administrative Services and Housing and Construction are taking action to ensure that wherever possible government owned and occupied buildings serving the general public are physically accessible to people with disabilities (Recs 2-4 (1980))
a Chair of Rehabilitation Studies, largely funded by the Department of Veterans' Affairs, has been established at Flinders University in South Australia. (Rec 1 (1978) and Rec 31 (1980))
the Office of Child Care is using a list of priority areas compiled by Council as a basis for ranking new project proposals affecting handicapped children and their families.
In other instances, the advice and views of the Council have been persuasive in encouraging State governments and others to take particular action.

The views, conclusions and recommendations of the Council remain active and are under continuing consideration by relevant Ministers, by the Standing Inter-Departmental Committee on Rehabilitation and through other co-ordinating mechanisms.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 3 December 1980:

(2) Are funding cut-backs being contemplated; if so, why.
(3) Is he able to say why this information became known to the Craft Council via a Craft Board Press release rather than through the Australia Council.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I am advised by the Australia Council that the Crafts Board has decided to reduce its funding to the Crafts Council of Australia. The Board has also separately decided not to continue its subsidy to the Crafts Council's publication project, 'Craft Australia' beyond December 1980. I am informed that the Crafts Board's decision derives from its recognition that the latest developments in the crafts confirm a trend to diverse and decentralised initiatives. The Crafts Board believes that the evolution of the Crafts Council of Australia and its constituent State Councils must take into account the expanded development of the State Councils, the growth of specialist interest groups and the roles of other agencies such as art galleries, craft centres, library networks and regional arts councils. It is the Board's view that, in response to these developments, the Crafts Council's national office must become a smaller flexible administrative unit, placing greater emphasis on a co-ordinating, directing and monitoring role and developing strategies on how best to utilise the potential of those other agencies in the interest of the crafts.

The Crafts Board's decision not to continue its subsidy to 'Craft Australia' beyond December 1980 relates to the Board's policy to give priority to support for the area of critical research and documentation, and that a potential market exists within the membership of the Crafts Council movement (currently estimated at 100,000) which would enable an increase in subscriptions from the current level of 6,000 to allow the journal to achieve self sufficiency.

(3) The Crafts Board has advised me that it did not issue a press release on this matter. I am informed that the matter was first discussed with the Crafts Council of Australia in November 1979 and, following its decision to withdraw from funding 'Craft Australia', the Board notified the Crafts Council of Australia by letter in January 1980 of its decision which was to take effect from the beginning of 1981.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Taxation Deductions: Mineral Exploration and Development

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: Was any taxation revenue forgone, or is it expected to be forgone, as a result of special deductions for expenditure on exploration and development of (a) petroleum and (b) other mineral resources in (i) 1979-80 and (ii) 1980-81; if so, what sum.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The income tax revenue forgone in the financial year 1979-80 as a result of the special deductions for expenditure on exploration and development of (a) petroleum and (b) other mineral resources allowed under Divisions 10AA and 10 of the Income Tax Assessment Act has been estimated as $28m and $43m respectively.

These amounts relate to the deduction of capital expenditure allowable under the special mining provisions, but not the ordinary provisions, of the income tax law. They also exclude the deductions under Division 10AAA relating to the transport of minerals. Revenue was also forgone in that certain deductions for expenditure on mineral exploration and development plant were allowed over shorter periods of time than would have been the case if the plant had been subject to depreciation allowances at normal rates. As indicated in the parts of the Statements attached to the Budget Speeches that relate to Industry Assistance throught the Taxation System, concessions that accelerate tax allowances in this way, while conferring no greater total deduction over the life of the plant than would otherwise be available, permit a deferment of tax which entails a cost to the Budget.
Statistics that would enable similar estimates to be made for 1980-81 are not yet available.
